[#SRC:12f21edd-7868-4706-b1f4-3b2e9af8d6aa] In applying these together, the Board should treat the weighted voting feature as a rights attribute of the relevant Shares and then ensure that all holders of Securities of that particular class or type are treated equally in respect of the rights attaching to that class or type, while recognizing that the rules contemplate departures from equality and proportionality in voting power/equity interest when Weighted Voting Rights are issued with approval. [#TGT:194cf07e-3ce5-429a-9d01-6e1c25bef4ae] [#SRC:12f21edd-7868-4706-b1f4-3b2e9af8d6aa]

question: If a PFP Operator is about to post a financing proposal for a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, what checks must it do on the PFP Prospect, and what related records does it have to keep for six years (including any documents involving a Body Corporate it set up for the transaction)?
gold_answer: Before a PFP Operator publishes a financing proposal about a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, it must first carry out due diligence on the PFP Prospect to help it meet the disclosure requirements placed on it by Rule 18.5.1. [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] That due diligence must include reviewing information the PFP Prospect provides about: (a) management details and background, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers; (b) the PFP Prospect’s background, including financial soundness, good standing, and (if relevant) regulatory status; and (c) the financing proposal, so that to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge the proposal is adequate, clear, fair, and not misleading. [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] After doing this work (and making the related disclosures), the PFP Operator must keep records for at least six years. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] The six-year record set must cover: all disclosures made under Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2, all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect, and the due diligence undertaken under Rule 18.4.1. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] Taken together, this means the PFP Operator should be able to show both what it reviewed before publication and what it disclosed, and preserve that evidence for the required retention period. [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]

question: For an Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business whose Financial Service Permission entitles them to hold Client Money, what must be submitted to the Regulator annually, and what specific statements must the Auditor include in that report as at the date of the Authorised Person's audited statement of financial position?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business whose Financial Service Permission entitles them to hold Client Money must arrange for a Client Money Auditor's Report to be submitted to the Regulator on an annual basis. [#SRC:c42abaa9-4c93-4d5b-b989-aa4ec57cf600] In procuring the production of that Client Money Auditor's Report, the Authorised Person must ensure the Auditor makes specified statements as at the date on which the Authorised Person’s audited statement of financial position was prepared. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] The report must cover both quantitative and qualitative matters, including: - The amount of Client Money the Authorised Person was holding and controlling in accordance with COBS Chapter 14 as at that date. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] - Whether, throughout the year, the Authorised Person maintained systems and controls to comply with the relevant provisions of COBS Chapter 14 and whether those controls keep Client Money identifiable and secure at all times. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] - Whether any COBS Chapter 14 requirements were not met, and whether Client Money was pooled in a single client Account or segregated in Client Accounts for individual Clients in accordance with COBS Chapter 14. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] - Whether the Auditor received all necessary information and explanations for preparing the report to the Regulator, and (if applicable) whether there were material discrepancies in Client Money reconciliation. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17]

question: If an Authorised Person is allowed (by its Financial Service Permission) to hold Client Money while doing Investment Business, what report has to go to the Regulator every year, and what does the Auditor have to say in it at the date of the audited statement of financial position?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business has a Financial Service Permission that allows it to hold Client Money, it must arrange for a Client Money Auditor’s Report to be submitted to the Regulator each year. [#SRC:c42abaa9-4c93-4d5b-b989-aa4ec57cf600] When the Authorised Person procures that report, it must ensure the Auditor includes specific statements measured as at the date the Authorised Person’s audited statement of financial position was prepared. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] At that financial-position date, the Auditor must state the amount of Client Money the Authorised Person was holding and controlling in line with COBS Chapter 14. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] The Auditor must also state whether the Authorised Person maintained systems and controls throughout the year to comply with COBS Chapter 14, and whether those controls keep Client Money identifiable and secure at all times. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] In addition, the Auditor must address whether any COBS Chapter 14 requirements were not met and whether Client Money was pooled in a single client Account or segregated into Client Accounts for individual Clients in accordance with COBS Chapter 14. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] Finally, the Auditor must confirm receiving necessary information and explanations for the report to the Regulator and, if applicable, note any material reconciliation discrepancies. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity is putting forecast financial information in its disclosure and that forecast comes from a Production Target, what must it say about its assumptions and the Production Target, and how does that fit with the FSRA’s expectation that the disclosure should be fair and balanced compared with the separate report that is attached as an annexure?
gold_answer: The disclosure needs to include a complete set of required assumption and Production Target information for the forecast, and it should be presented in a way that is fair and balanced when compared with the attached separate report, without trying to restate everything in that report. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:b8cb4fdb-f627-43ae-90bf-801a549f8d63] For the forecast financial information, the Mining Reporting Entity must include all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast and also include all other material assumptions used. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If it believes the material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it must state that and explain the methodology it used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] It must also include the Production Target that the forecast is based on, and that Production Target must include all information required by Rule 11.8.3. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Separately, where the disclosure includes information that comes from the separate report prepared under Rule 11.6.2 (which must be attached as an annexure), the information in the disclosure must be a fair and balanced representation of that report; however, the FSRA does not expect a full summary, only the material information needed to understand the estimates of Mineral Resources in the separate report that is not already in the body of the disclosure. [#TGT:b8cb4fdb-f627-43ae-90bf-801a549f8d63]

question: Where a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a Rule 11.8.2 disclosure that complied with the detailed content requirements for Production Targets, under what conditions may a later disclosure about the same Production Target omit the Rule 11.8.2 content items (including the required prominent cautionary statements for Inferred Mineral Resources and/or an Exploration Target), and what specific confirmations or cross-references must the later disclosure still include?
gold_answer: A subsequent disclosure about a Production Target can omit the detailed Rule 11.8.2 content (such as the material assumptions, proportion breakdowns, and the specified prominent cautionary statements) only if it is explicitly tied back to an earlier Rule 11.8.2 disclosure that already contained those required items and was compliant. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] To rely on that streamlined approach, the later disclosure must (i) point readers to the earlier compliant disclosure, and (ii) include a confirmation that the material assumptions used in the initial disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] In addition, the later disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, aligned to the specific statement required for that scenario in the Rule 11.8.2 content list. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] Similarly, if the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement aligned to the Exploration Target warning specified in the Rule 11.8.2 requirements. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity already made a full Rule 11.8.2 Production Target disclosure, when can it make a later update without repeating all the details (like the assumptions and the split between Ore Reserves/Mineral Resources/Exploration Target), and what must it still say if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or partly based on an Exploration Target?
gold_answer: A later disclosure about a Production Target does not have to repeat all the detailed Rule 11.8.2 information (for example, the material economic assumptions and other material assumptions, whether forecast commodity prices were used on reasonable grounds, and the proportions sourced from Ore Reserves, Mineral Resources, Inferred Mineral Resources, and any Exploration Target) if it properly relies on an earlier Rule 11.8.2 disclosure that already included those items and was compliant. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] To do that, the later disclosure must refer back to the earlier compliant disclosure and must also confirm that the material assumptions from the initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] Even when the later disclosure is streamlined, it still needs to include specific prominent warnings in certain cases: if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the later disclosure must include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement matching the required Inferred Mineral Resources warning for that scenario. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] If the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement matching the required Exploration Target warning. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]

question: Where an MTF admits to trading Securities offered by way of an Exempt Offer under MKT Rule 4.3.1 (13), how should the operator align its platform-specific systems and controls (including identifying offerees and limiting non-Professional Client participation) with the broader Rule 3.9.1 admission-to-trading framework that requires clear, transparent Business Rules and fair, orderly and efficient trading?
gold_answer: An MTF admitting Securities from an Exempt Offer under MKT Rule 4.3.1 (13) must implement platform-level systems and controls that both (i) enforce the Exempt Offer-specific constraints and (ii) support compliance with the admission-to-trading requirements referenced through Rule 3.9.1. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] Concretely, the MTF must ensure it admits only Securities from Exempt Offers made on its own platform, can identify the Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made, and restrict trading so that no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients can trade those Securities. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] In parallel, because the MTF must comply with MIR rule 3.9.1 (Admission to trading) as applicable for the relevant Securities, the admission approach should be reflected in clear and transparent Business Rules and should ensure the admitted instruments are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] Operationally, this means the Exempt Offer gating (platform-only admission, offeree identification, and the 200-person non-Professional Client cap) should be embedded into the admission process and rule set used to meet Rule 3.9.1 expectations on transparency and orderly trading. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]

question: How do the Regulations’ general prohibition on making an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market (and on having Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange) interact with the Regulator’s power under section 59(c) of the FSMR to prescribe certain communications as Exempt Communications, and what is the compliance consequence for those prescribed communications?
gold_answer: Communications that the Regulator prescribes as Exempt Communications are treated as outside the regulatory concept that triggers the general prohibition on making an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or having Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange. [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f] The Regulations state that a person must not make an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market and must not have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, unless an exception applies under the Regulations. [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a] Under section 59(c) of the FSMR, the Regulator can designate certain communications as Exempt Communications, and those communications are not subject to the prohibition in section 58(1) of the FSMR because they fall outside the definition of an “Offer of Securities” in section 59 of the FSMR. [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f] As a result, where a communication has been prescribed by the Regulator as an Exempt Communication, it does not constitute an Offer of Securities for these purposes, so the Regulations’ prohibition framed around making an “Offer of Securities” in the Abu Dhabi Global Market is not engaged by that communication. [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f] [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a]

question: For a Petroleum Reporting Entity preparing a Summary of Reserves and Resources, when must it include the MKT Form 12-1 table and what is the relevant “as of” date constraint, and how does this change if the entity is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC?
gold_answer: A Petroleum Reporting Entity generally must include, within its Summary of Reserves and Resources, a table using the MKT Form 12-1 format, and that table must be prepared “as of” a date that is no earlier than one month before the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed. [#SRC:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] However, if the Petroleum Reporting Entity is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC, it is not required to comply with Rule 12.14.1, which is the rule that imposes the MKT Form 12-1 table requirement and its timing condition. [#TGT:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1] In practical terms, the compliance outcome depends on whether the entity falls into that SEC annual filing category: if it does not, it must include the MKT Form 12-1 table and ensure the “as of” date is within the one-month window before disclosure; if it does, the entity is exempt from the Rule 12.14.1 obligation and therefore does not have to meet that table-inclusion requirement or its associated “as of” date constraint under that rule. [#SRC:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] [#TGT:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1]

question: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity is putting together its Summary of Reserves and Resources, what table does it normally need to add and how recent must the table’s “as of” date be, and does that still apply if it files SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports every year?
gold_answer: Normally, a Petroleum Reporting Entity must add a table to its Summary of Reserves and Resources using the MKT Form 12-1 format. [#SRC:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] The table must be dated “as of” a point in time that is not more than one month before the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed, meaning the “as of” date cannot be earlier than one month prior to that disclosure. [#SRC:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] But this requirement does not apply in the same way to every Petroleum Reporting Entity: if the entity is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC, it does not have to comply with Rule 12.14.1. [#TGT:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1] Because the MKT Form 12-1 table and its one-month “as of” date condition are part of Rule 12.14.1, an entity in that SEC annual filing category is not required to follow that table-and-date requirement under Rule 12.14.1, while an entity outside that category must follow it when preparing the Summary of Reserves and Resources. [#SRC:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] [#TGT:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1]

question: When the Regulator receives a request from a Host Regulator to conduct an on-site inspection relating to a Passported Fund, how should the Regulator determine whether it must permit and accompany the inspection versus when it may refuse to cooperate, particularly where enforcement action or judicial proceedings exist for the same conduct and the same Persons?
gold_answer: The Regulator’s default position, when it receives a Host Regulator request to carry out an on-site inspection connected to a Passported Fund, is to allow the inspection to proceed and to accompany the Host Regulator during the on-site visit. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6] However, the Regulator may decline to act on a Host Regulator’s cooperation request for an inspection if specific parallel actions already exist concerning the same conduct and the same Persons. [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c] In practice, the Regulator should (i) confirm that the request is for an on-site inspection and that it is in relation to a Passported Fund, because that is the trigger for the permit-and-accompany approach; and then (ii) assess whether either refusal circumstance applies. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6] The refusal circumstances are limited to cases where the Regulator has already started or finished enforcement action about the same conduct and the same Persons, or where judicial proceedings have already been started or finished about the same conduct and the same Persons. [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c] If neither of those circumstances applies, the Regulator should permit the inspection and accompany it during the on-site inspection. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information under Rule 11.9.1 and treats its material economic assumptions as commercially sensitive, what specific statements and explanatory content must it provide, and how does that disclosure need to connect to the Production Target from which the forecast is derived (including the Rule 11.8.3 information)?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity that discloses forecast financial information under Rule 11.9.1 must still provide a complete, investor-understandable explanation of how its forecast is built, even if it treats material economic assumptions as commercially sensitive. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In that scenario, it must (i) identify all material economic assumptions used, and (ii) if it considers those assumptions commercially sensitive, include an explicit statement that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine them. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Where it relies on the relevant guidance, it must also explain why the information is considered a trade secret or commercially sensitive and disclose enough information—potentially using narrative rather than numbers—to allow investors to understand the methodology used to determine the factors and assumptions and the basis for reporting estimates of Ore Reserves. [#TGT:6435d936-1f1e-44c9-a788-2a4f4de44b80] Separately, the Rule 11.9.1 disclosure must identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived and include all information required by Rule 11.8.3 for that Production Target. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] The commercially sensitive treatment does not remove the need to provide sufficient methodological context for investors, including the basis for Ore Reserves estimates. [#TGT:6435d936-1f1e-44c9-a788-2a4f4de44b80]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity is sharing forecast financial information and says its key economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, what does it still have to tell investors, and what Production Target details must it include with the forecast?
gold_answer: Even if a Mining Reporting Entity says its key economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it still has to give investors enough information to understand how it built the forecast and what it is based on. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] For the forecast disclosure, it must cover the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, including all material economic assumptions and any other material assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If it treats the material economic assumptions as commercially sensitive, it must say so and explain the methodology it used to determine those assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In the commercially sensitive case described for Ore Reserves reporting, it should also explain why the information is considered a trade secret or commercially sensitive and must still disclose sufficient information (which may be narrative rather than numerical) so investors can understand the methodology used to determine the relevant factors and assumptions and the basis for reporting estimates of Ore Reserves. [#TGT:6435d936-1f1e-44c9-a788-2a4f4de44b80] In addition, the forecast disclosure must state the Production Target from which the forecast is derived and include all the information that Rule 11.8.3 requires for that Production Target. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]

question: Where a person is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, and an investor who acquired Securities suffers loss from an untrue or misleading statement or a material omission in that Prospectus, what publication-related steps (and timing relative to acquisition) can prevent that person from incurring liability for the loss, including the case where the issue is that an Expert was not competent or did not consent?
gold_answer: A person who is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus can be liable to pay compensation to an acquirer of the relevant Securities for loss or damage caused by an untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus, or by omitting a material matter that was required to be included. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] However, that person does not incur liability for loss in respect of the Securities if, before the Securities were acquired, either (i) a correction was published in a way intended to reach persons likely to acquire those Securities, or (ii) where the statement is of the type attributed to an Expert, the fact that the Expert was not competent or had not consented to inclusion of the attributed statement was published in that same attention-getting manner. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] Alternatively, liability is avoided if the person took all steps that it was reasonable to take to secure that publication and, on reasonable grounds, believed the publication had occurred before the Securities were acquired. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] The key linkage is that the compensation exposure tied to untrue/misleading statements or material omissions is addressed by timely, appropriately targeted publication (or reasonable efforts and belief of publication) occurring before acquisition. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b]

question: If someone is on the list in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, and a buyer of the Securities loses money because the Prospectus had a misleading statement or left out a required material matter, what can that liable person do (and by when) to avoid liability—especially if the problem is about an Expert’s competence or consent?
gold_answer: If a person is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, that person can have to pay compensation to someone who acquired the Securities covered by the Prospectus and suffered loss or damage because the Prospectus contained an untrue or misleading statement or omitted a material matter that was required to be included. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] Even in that setting, the person avoids incurring liability for the loss if, before the Securities were acquired, a correction is published in a way meant to bring it to the attention of people likely to buy those Securities. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] If the issue is a statement attributed to an Expert, the same timing and publication approach can be used by publishing that the Expert was not competent or did not consent to having the attributed statement included in the Prospectus. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] A second route is available: the person can avoid liability if they took all steps that were reasonable to secure that publication and reasonably believed it had happened before the Securities were acquired. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] In short, the compensation risk tied to misleading statements or required omissions is addressed by timely publication (or reasonable efforts and belief of publication) before acquisition. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b]

question: For a Mining Production Reporting Entity preparing its quarterly report, how should it satisfy the requirement to provide the Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once every 12 months, and what date constraint applies to the MKT Form 11-1 table included in that Summary when it is disclosed (including when the Summary is instead included in the annual report)?
gold_answer: A Mining Production Reporting Entity must ensure that, across its quarterly reporting cycle, it provides the Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once in every 12-month period, unless that Summary is instead provided in the Mining Reporting Entity’s annual report. [#SRC:a24b4f51-4c48-4846-bd22-d5f98dbad55b] When the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed (whether via a quarterly report to meet the 12‑month cadence or via inclusion in the annual report), the Mining Reporting Entity’s Summary must contain a table in the format of MKT Form 11-1. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd] The table must be prepared “as of” a date that is not earlier than one month before the disclosure date of the Summary of Reserves and Resources, meaning the table’s effective date must fall within the month leading up to the Summary’s disclosure. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd] In addition, the quarterly report must state when the prior disclosure of this 12‑monthly Summary occurred and when the next such disclosure is expected to occur, so readers can track the timing of the required Summary disclosures. [#SRC:a24b4f51-4c48-4846-bd22-d5f98dbad55b]

question: Where a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a disclosure that complied with Rule 11.9.2 and later makes a subsequent disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, under what conditions may the subsequent disclosure omit the Rule 11.9.2 information, and what specific “at least equally prominent, and proximate” cautionary statement(s) must be included if the underlying Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or is based in part on an Exploration Target?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may leave out the Rule 11.9.2 content in a later disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target only if the later disclosure (i) points back to an earlier disclosure that itself complied with Rule 11.9.2 and (ii) confirms that the material assumptions from that initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] In addition, the later disclosure must include specific cautionary language, presented at least equally prominently and close to the forecast financial information, when certain Production Target bases apply. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] If the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the required proximate cautionary statement is the one set out for that scenario, warning that geological confidence is low, further work is needed, there is no certainty the Production Target will be met or realised, and that investors should not rely solely on the Production Target when making investment decisions. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] If the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, the required proximate cautionary statement is the one explaining that the Exploration Target is conceptual, exploration is insufficient to determine a Mineral Resource, and there is no certainty further work will result in Mineral Resources or that the Production Target will be realised. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity already made an earlier disclosure that met Rule 11.9.2, what does it need to do in a later announcement with forecast financial information from a Production Target so it can skip repeating the Rule 11.9.2 details, and what warning statement must it put next to the forecast financial information when the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources?
gold_answer: The later announcement can avoid repeating the Rule 11.9.2 information only if it clearly refers back to the earlier disclosure that was compliant with Rule 11.9.2 and includes a confirmation that the material assumptions used in that initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] Even when that “no repetition” approach is used, the later announcement must still add specific cautionary language in certain cases, and it must be placed at least equally prominently and close to the forecast financial information. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] When the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the required warning is the prescribed statement explaining that the geological confidence for inferred mineral resources is low, that further evaluation and/or exploration is required to establish sufficient confidence, and that there is no certainty the work will lead to indicated mineral resources or that the production target will be realised. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] It must also state that the production target reflects current expectations of future results or events and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]

question: How must an Authorised Person determine the risk weight for (i) a corporate-asset-class CR Exposure that is unrated (no external credit assessment by a recognised external credit rating agency) and (ii) an unrated short term CR Exposure to a corporate where another short term issue-specific external credit assessment for that corporate attracts a 50% or 100% risk weight, taking into account the corporate risk-weight table and the higher-of comparison to the central government risk weight?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must apply the corporate-asset-class risk-weight table as the baseline method for corporate exposures, including the table’s unrated category, but must also apply the specific higher-of and floor rules that override that baseline in the circumstances described. [#TGT:ee286214-80b1-480f-8be1-055c442795e4] For a corporate CR Exposure that has no external credit assessment by a recognised external credit rating agency, the risk weight is the higher of (i) the risk weight determined under the table referenced for such exposures and (ii) the risk weight applicable to a CR Exposure to the central government of the jurisdiction where the corporate is incorporated or established. [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad] Separately, where there is a short term corporate exposure with an issue-specific external credit assessment that results in a 50% or 100% risk weight, any unrated short term CR Exposure to the same corporate must not be assigned a risk weight below 100%, even if the table’s unrated row would otherwise be used as the starting point. [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad] In practice, this means the table’s unrated risk weight (100%) will typically align with the minimum required for those unrated short term exposures, while the higher-of test can still require a higher figure if the relevant central government risk weight is higher. [#TGT:ee286214-80b1-480f-8be1-055c442795e4] [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad]

question: When applying the corporate asset class risk-weight table, how must an Authorised Person treat an unrated CR Exposure (long term or short term) to a corporate if a short term issue-specific external credit assessment for that corporate attracts a 150% risk weight, and how does this interact with the table’s unrated risk weight?
gold_answer: The corporate risk-weight table provides an unrated risk weight for corporate-asset-class CR Exposures, but a specific rule requires a higher risk weight in the stated 150% scenario. [#TGT:ee286214-80b1-480f-8be1-055c442795e4] If a short term CR Exposure in the corporate asset class has an issue-specific external credit assessment that attracts a 150% risk weight, the Authorised Person must apply a 150% risk weight to any unrated CR Exposure to the same corporate, regardless of whether that unrated exposure is long term or short term. [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad] This requirement effectively overrides the table’s unrated row (which otherwise indicates 100% for unrated corporate exposures) for exposures to that same corporate once the triggering 150% short term assessed exposure exists. [#TGT:ee286214-80b1-480f-8be1-055c442795e4] [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad] The operational consequence is that the Authorised Person cannot default to the table’s unrated risk weight in this case; instead, the unrated exposure must be aligned to 150% because the assessed short term exposure signals that higher risk weight for the corporate. [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad] The table remains relevant as the general framework for corporate risk weights, but the specific 150% linkage rule governs the unrated exposures to the same corporate in this defined circumstance. [#TGT:ee286214-80b1-480f-8be1-055c442795e4] [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad]

question: For a Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession that files late, how do the texts connect the $500 late payment fee to the specific type of Regulatory Filing referenced in Rule 1.2.7, and what additional consequence may follow from the late submission?
gold_answer: A Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession that submits a Regulatory Filing after the due date must pay a $500 late payment fee to the Regulator, and the late submission also constitutes a breach with potential further regulatory action beyond the fee. [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105] [#SRC:2932ae57-5946-46b4-8ac2-e41d4d145bcc] The linkage to Rule 1.2.7 is that, for Designated Non-Financial Businesses or Professions, Rule 1.2.7 is specifically tied to the AML Return, which is required by Rule 4.6.1 in the Anti-Money Laundering and Sanctions Rules and Guidance Rulebook. [#SRC:2932ae57-5946-46b4-8ac2-e41d4d145bcc] Accordingly, when the late-filed Regulatory Filing is the AML Return in that context, the $500 fee described for late Regulatory Filings applies, and it is imposed in addition to the breach outcome. [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105] [#SRC:2932ae57-5946-46b4-8ac2-e41d4d145bcc] Beyond paying the fee, the Regulator may take further action following the late submission. [#SRC:2932ae57-5946-46b4-8ac2-e41d4d145bcc]

question: Where a Fund Manager identifies a material change, error, or omission after making the notification under Rule 3.1.2 but before Promotion begins in a Host Jurisdiction, what are the Fund Manager’s immediate notification duties, what must the Regulator do with that information, and how can that same type of issue lead to the Regulator taking measures up to de-registration if it results in non-compliance?
gold_answer: Between the notification under Rule 3.1.2 and the start of Promotion in a Host Jurisdiction, the Fund Manager must notify the Regulator in writing without delay if it becomes aware of any material change, error, or omission that is reasonably likely to be relevant to that notification. [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6] After receiving that notice, the Regulator must promptly pass all relevant details of the material change, error, or omission to the relevant Host Regulator. [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6] Separately, if a material change, error, or omission of the type referred to in Rule 3.1.9 results in the Fund Manager no longer complying with applicable legislation (including these Rules), the Regulator is required to take all due measures. [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207] Those measures can include, where necessary, de-registering the Private Fund from the Register of Passported Funds in accordance with these Rules, and the Regulator may also act where it otherwise considers action necessary and appropriate in the circumstances. [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207] In practice, the Fund Manager’s prompt written notice during the pre-Promotion window enables the Regulator’s onward communication to the Host Regulator while also informing whether the issue triggers due measures for non-compliance, potentially up to de-registration. [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6] [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207]

question: If the Fund Manager spots a relevant material change, error, or omission after it has sent the Rule 3.1.2 notification but before Promotion starts in a Host Jurisdiction, what should it do right away, what will the Regulator do next, and what could happen if that issue means the Fund Manager no longer complies with applicable legislation (including these Rules)?
gold_answer: In the period after the Rule 3.1.2 notification and before Promotion begins in a Host Jurisdiction, the Fund Manager must act quickly: once it becomes aware of a material change, error, or omission that is reasonably likely to matter to that notification, it must send written notice to the Regulator without delay. [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6] The Regulator then has its own follow-on step: it will promptly give the relevant Host Regulator all relevant details about the material change, error, or omission. [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6] Beyond that communication chain, the same kind of issue can have more serious consequences if it leads to non-compliance: where, because of a material change, error, or omission referred to in Rule 3.1.9, the Fund Manager would no longer comply with applicable legislation (including these Rules), the Regulator must take all due measures. [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207] Those measures can go as far as de-registering the Private Fund from the Register of Passported Funds, and the Regulator may also take measures when it considers that necessary and appropriate in the circumstances. [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207]

question: How should a PFP Operator align its six-year record-retention duties with its obligation to publish due-diligence-related information to PFP Clients on the Private Financing Platform, particularly where the due diligence is undertaken under Rule 18.4.1?
gold_answer: A PFP Operator must both (i) keep specified records for at least six years and (ii) publish specified due-diligence information for PFP Clients on the Private Financing Platform it operates; the two obligations should be implemented together so the published due-diligence description is supportable by retained evidence. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] The record-keeping duty applies to the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1, as well as to all disclosures made under Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2 and documentation exchanged between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] Separately, the publication duty includes making available to PFP Clients the methodology of, and limitations to, the due diligence undertaken by the PFP Operator concerning each PFP Prospect identified on the platform, in accordance with Rule 18.4.1. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] Practically, the PFP Operator should retain, for the six-year minimum, the underlying due-diligence work and related communications so it can substantiate the published methodology/limitations and keep a consistent compliance trail across what is disclosed/published and what is documented. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f]

question: When a PFP Operator uses a Body Corporate as an intermediary between a PFP Client and a PFP Prospect, what combined requirements apply to (i) publishing governance/operational arrangements and (ii) retaining transaction-related documentation, and what is the minimum retention period?
gold_answer: Where a PFP Operator uses a Body Corporate as an intermediary, it must address both transparency to PFP Clients via platform publication and documentary retention for a defined period. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] On the publication side, the PFP Operator must ensure information available to PFP Clients is published on the Private Financing Platform, including the governance and operational arrangements of any Body Corporate used as an intermediary between a PFP Client and any PFP Prospect. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] On the record-retention side, the PFP Operator must maintain and keep, for a minimum of six years, all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] Read together, this means the PFP Operator should (i) publish the Body Corporate’s governance/operational arrangements for PFP Clients to review and (ii) preserve the related transaction documentation involving that Body Corporate for at least six years, so the intermediary structure described to clients is supported by a retained record of how the intermediary was used in practice. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]

question: When a Relevant Person conducts business entirely in an NFTF manner and uses eKYC, how should its risk assessment and AML/TFS control framework be structured so that it both mitigates the distinct NFTF/eKYC risks and meets the requirement for regular risk assessments of AML/TFS systems and controls?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person should integrate its NFTF/eKYC-specific risk assessment into its broader AML/TFS systems and controls so that the assessment both identifies concrete mitigation actions for NFTF business (including eKYC) and also tests whether the overall AML/TFS framework remains adequate over time. [#SRC:c24c6dfe-b5fa-4802-81ab-5894795d4362] [#TGT:f0c3d08f-8696-42f8-b449-86c97c8f6d4d] The risk assessment should explicitly address that risks can differ when business is conducted entirely in an NFTF manner versus a relationship that mixes face-to-face and NFTF interactions, and it should set out actions to mitigate those NFTF and eKYC risks. [#SRC:c24c6dfe-b5fa-4802-81ab-5894795d4362] In parallel, the Relevant Person must establish and maintain effective policies, procedures, systems and controls to prevent opportunities for money laundering in relation to the Relevant Person and its activities, and it must ensure regular risk assessments are carried out on the adequacy of those AML/TFS systems and controls so they continue to enable identification, assessment, monitoring and management of money laundering risk in a comprehensive and proportionate way. [#TGT:f0c3d08f-8696-42f8-b449-86c97c8f6d4d] To make the NFTF/eKYC assessment actionable within that framework, it should reference risk mitigation measures recommended by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and other relevant bodies. [#SRC:c24c6dfe-b5fa-4802-81ab-5894795d4362]

question: How should a Relevant Person evidence that its regular risk assessments of AML/TFS systems and controls remain comprehensive and proportionate where the business relationship is entirely NFTF and relies on eKYC, including what external mitigation measures the assessment should draw on?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person can evidence this by ensuring its regular risk assessments explicitly cover the distinct risk profile of conducting business entirely in an NFTF manner and using eKYC, and by linking the resulting mitigation actions to the ongoing adequacy of its AML/TFS systems and controls. [#SRC:c24c6dfe-b5fa-4802-81ab-5894795d4362] [#TGT:f0c3d08f-8696-42f8-b449-86c97c8f6d4d] The assessment should recognize that different risks are likely to arise where business is conducted entirely NFTF compared with a mix of face-to-face and NFTF interactions, and it should identify actions to mitigate risks associated with NFTF business generally and eKYC specifically. [#SRC:c24c6dfe-b5fa-4802-81ab-5894795d4362] At the same time, the Relevant Person must ensure that regular risk assessments are carried out on the adequacy of its AML/TFS systems and controls so they continue to enable it to identify, assess, monitor and manage money laundering risk adequately, and so that those systems and controls remain comprehensive and proportionate to the nature, scale and complexity of its activities. [#TGT:f0c3d08f-8696-42c8-b449-86c97c8f6d4d] To support the mitigation component of the NFTF/eKYC assessment, it should make reference to risk mitigation measures recommended by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and other relevant bodies. [#SRC:c24c6dfe-b5fa-4802-81ab-5894795d4362]

question: When the Regulator is satisfied that action is in the interest(s) of the ADGM/Abu Dhabi Global Market, what directions may it give to a Reporting Entity, and what additional power (beyond directing disclosure or other steps) may it exercise, including how it may frame those requirements?
gold_answer: If the Regulator is satisfied that it is in the interest of the ADGM/Abu Dhabi Global Market, it may issue a direction to a Reporting Entity requiring disclosure of specified information or requiring the Reporting Entity to take other steps the Regulator considers appropriate. [#SRC:b83c251c-65fd-4f1c-9225-20fa42145c35] [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94] The TARGET clarifies that the disclosure direction can be framed as disclosure “to the market,” and it also confirms that the Regulator’s direction power is not limited to disclosure/steps: it may additionally impose extra continuing obligations on the Reporting Entity. [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94] In exercising these powers, the Regulator may set the terms and conditions it determines for the direction or the additional continuing obligations. [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94] The SOURCE provides the statutory basis that the Regulator’s power is triggered by its satisfaction that acting is in the interest of the ADGM and that the direction can require disclosure of specified information or other steps the Regulator considers appropriate. [#SRC:b83c251c-65fd-4f1c-9225-20fa42145c35] Taken together, the passages indicate that, once the Regulator reaches the relevant “interest” satisfaction, it can (i) direct disclosure of specified information (including to the market) or other steps, and (ii) separately impose additional continuing obligations, each potentially subject to Regulator-determined terms and conditions. [#SRC:b83c251c-65fd-4f1c-9225-20fa42145c35] [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94]

question: If an Authorised Person runs a Multilateral Trading Facility for Virtual Assets, what does it need to do with GEN Rule 5.2.14 (especially the word “Investment”), and which other rule sets does it have to follow for that activity (including what changes if it also provides custody)?
gold_answer: When an Authorised Person is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, GEN Rule 5.2.14 applies to that Authorised Person, and the rule must be read so that any mention of “Investment” is understood to mean “Virtual Asset”. [#TGT:726a7101-d094-4454-93b6-5e5561582705] This requirement is not standalone: it applies on top of the general requirements that already apply to an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets under Rules 17.1–17.6. [#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e5066d40d24] In addition, for the Multilateral Trading Facility activity, the Authorised Person must comply with the requirements in COBS, MIR and GEN as set out in Rules 17.7.2–17.7.6, which is the broader rulebook context that includes GEN Rule 5.2.14. [#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e5066d40d24] If the Authorised Person is also Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets, it must also comply with Rule 17.8, in addition to the Multilateral Trading Facility requirements and the GEN Rule 5.2.14 reading described above. [#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e5066d40d24]

question: When an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA, how must it reflect that collateral in the RWA(CR) calculation—specifically, how are E and CRW determined for the collateralised and uncollateralised portions under the general RWA(CR) = E x CRW approach?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA may reflect the collateral as a CRM effect by splitting the CR Exposure into two parts and then applying the standard RWA(CR) computation to each part. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] Under the general approach, the firm calculates RWA for CR Exposures by determining an Exposure value (E), determining the applicable risk weight (CRW), and applying the formula RWA(CR) = E x CRW, then summing across exposures. [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368] For the collateralised portion, E must be set to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and CRW must be the risk weight applicable to that collateral as if the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to it. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] For the uncollateralised portion, E must be the original E of the CR Exposure reduced by the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and CRW must be the risk weight applicable to the obligor. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] The resulting RWA(CR) amounts for the two portions are calculated using RWA(CR) = E x CRW and then included in the total RWA by adding the RWA amounts across all CR Exposures. [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368]

question: Before a Relevant Person appoints a service provider to undertake CDD, how should the Relevant Person structure the required initial assurance assessment so that it also supports the assurance expectations applicable when assessing an eKYC System for the purpose of Rule 9.3.1A, and what documentation must be in place at appointment?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person should design the pre-appointment assurance work so it both (i) evaluates whether the service provider is suitable to undertake CDD and (ii) aligns with the assurance approach expected when assessing an eKYC System for the purpose of Rule 9.3.1A. [#TGT:1f815e39-1a9b-4f7d-af18-65b633fed752] [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4] In practice, this means the initial assurance assessment conducted before appointment should be scoped to test whether any eKYC System involved is reliable and independent and whether it enables the Relevant Person to comply with all applicable Rules of the Regulator, because those are the assurance outcomes the Relevant Person should seek to establish for Rule 9.3.1A purposes. [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4] The Relevant Person should also consider applying relevant assurance standards guidance issued by the Regulator, competent U.A.E. authorities, FATF, and other standard-setting bodies as part of how it conducts and benchmarks that assessment. [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4] Separately, as a condition of appointing the service provider, the Relevant Person must ensure the service provider’s obligations are clearly documented in a binding agreement, and this documentation must be in place prior to appointment. [#TGT:1f815e39-1a9b-4f7d-af18-65b633fed752]

question: If a Relevant Person is about to hire a service provider to do CDD and that work will use an eKYC System, what should the Relevant Person check in the initial assurance assessment, and what must be written down before the hire happens?
gold_answer: Before hiring the service provider, the Relevant Person must carry out an initial assurance assessment to judge whether the service provider is suitable to undertake CDD, and the Relevant Person must have the service provider’s obligations clearly set out in a binding agreement before the appointment is made. [#TGT:1f815e39-1a9b-4f7d-af18-65b633fed752] Where the arrangement involves an eKYC System and the assurance work is being undertaken for the purpose of Rule 9.3.1A, the Relevant Person should use the assessment to establish that the eKYC System is reliable and independent and that it allows the Relevant Person to comply with all applicable Rules of the Regulator. [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4] To strengthen how the assessment is performed, the Relevant Person should also consider applying assurance standards guidance from the Regulator, competent U.A.E. authorities, FATF, and other relevant standard-setting bodies. [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4] Taken together, the pre-appointment steps are: assess suitability of the service provider for CDD, test the eKYC System against reliability/independence and compliance enablement expectations, and document the service provider’s obligations in a binding agreement before appointment. [#TGT:1f815e39-1a9b-4f7d-af18-65b633fed752] [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation and later makes a subsequent disclosure about those same Non-Equivalent Estimates, how can it both (i) rely on the carve-out from Rule 11.2.1(1) and (ii) avoid repeating the information required by Rule 11.7.3 in the later disclosure?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity can avoid complying with Rule 11.2.1(1) for a disclosure of material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation only if it instead complies with the specified alternative set of rules, which includes Rule 11.7.3. [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] If the entity has already made a Non-Equivalent Estimates disclosure that complied with Rule 11.7.3, then a later disclosure about those same Non-Equivalent Estimates may omit the information required by Rule 11.7.3, but only if the later disclosure meets all of the conditions tied to that omission. [#TGT:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] Practically, to achieve both outcomes, the Mining Reporting Entity should: - Ensure the initial disclosure of the material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation is made in a way that satisfies the alternative compliance pathway (including Rule 11.7.2, Rule 11.7.3, Rule 11.7.4, and Rule 11.7.6), so Rule 11.2.1(1) is not required for that disclosure. [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] - In the subsequent disclosure, reference the earlier Rule 11.7.3-compliant disclosure and confirm both that the earlier Rule 11.7.3 information still applies and that there is no new material information or data affecting reliability/interpretation or the entity’s ability to verify the estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#TGT:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] - Include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement addressing the matters covered by Rule 11.7.3(1). [#TGT:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4]

question: Before an Authorised Person opens a trading account that enables a Retail Client to buy and sell OTC Leveraged Products, what onboarding steps must the Authorised Person complete regarding the risk disclosure statement and the Retail Client’s acknowledgement, and what specific warnings and risk statements must that risk disclosure statement contain (including any stop-loss explanation conditions)?
gold_answer: Before opening a trading account that allows a Retail Client to trade OTC Leveraged Products, the Authorised Person must complete onboarding actions tied to both delivery of a compliant risk disclosure statement and documented client acknowledgement. [#SRC:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8] The Authorised Person must provide a separate risk disclosure statement as part of onboarding in sufficient time before it carries on any business for that Retail Client, obtain a documented acknowledgement that the Retail Client received and reviewed the statement and understands and accepts the risks, give the Retail Client a duplicate copy of that acknowledgement, and keep a record of the acknowledgement in line with applicable record-keeping requirements. [#SRC:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8] The risk disclosure statement used for this onboarding must include a prominent warning that the Retail Client may lose substantially more than the initial margin posted and must also state, among other points, that it may not cover all risks, that the Retail Client may lose all capital outlay and any unredeemed profits, that losses can accumulate rapidly, that leverage amplifies losses, that loss-mitigation systems (including stop-loss limits) may fail, that slippage can occur, and that most Retail Clients lose money. [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955] Where stop-loss orders are relevant, the statement must explain them and clearly indicate whether a stop-loss is “guaranteed,” and if not, that it may not limit losses during highly volatile conditions. [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955]

question: When an Authorised Person is preparing the separate risk disclosure statement to be provided in good time during onboarding (before carrying on any business for a Retail Client) for OTC Leveraged Products, which content elements must be included to support the documented acknowledgement that the Retail Client understands and accepts the risks?
gold_answer: To support obtaining a documented acknowledgement that a Retail Client has received, reviewed, and understands and accepts the risks of trading OTC Leveraged Products, the Authorised Person must ensure the onboarding risk disclosure statement is both timely and substantively complete. [#SRC:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8] Procedurally, the Authorised Person must provide a separate risk disclosure statement as part of onboarding in sufficient time before it carries on any business for the Retail Client, then obtain the documented acknowledgement, provide the Retail Client with a duplicate copy of that acknowledgement, and retain a record of it under applicable record-keeping requirements. [#SRC:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8] Substantively, the risk disclosure statement must contain a prominent warning that the Retail Client can lose substantially more than the initial margin posted. [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955] It must further state that it may not address all risks; that the Retail Client may lose all capital outlay and any profits not redeemed; that losses can arise and accumulate quickly; that leverage and margin trading amplify losses; that stop-loss limits and other controls may be ineffective or fail; that slippage (differences between approved and executed prices) can occur; and that most Retail Clients lose money when transacting in OTC Leveraged Products. [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955] Where relevant, it must also explain stop-loss orders and clarify whether they are guaranteed, and if not, that they may not cap losses in highly volatile conditions. [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955]

question: When considering whether to support or give full effect to a Foreign Resolution Action by exercising Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers (including any need for ex-ante judicial approval under section 27), in what circumstances may the Regulator refuse to recognise the Foreign Resolution Action in whole or in part?
gold_answer: The Regulator may decline to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action (in full or only for certain parts) even where the contemplated next step would be to support or give full effect to it through the use of Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers (and even if ex-ante judicial approval under section 27 would otherwise be relevant to that exercise). [#TGT:5798f720-7021-4b63-9ebe-f1a30aebee29] Refusal is available if the Regulator is satisfied that at least one specified condition applies. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] Those conditions include: recognition would harm financial stability in the ADGM; the Resolution Conditions have not been met for the relevant entity listed in section 2 in connection with the Regulator’s proposed Resolution Action under section 78(5); or Resolution Action in relation to an ADGM Branch under section 78(5) is not needed to meet one or more Resolution Objectives. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] The Regulator may also refuse recognition if the foreign action would treat creditors located or payable in the ADGM differently (in treatment or legal rights) solely because of their ADGM location compared with creditors (including depositors) in the relevant non-ADGM jurisdiction. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] Finally, refusal is permitted where recognition and supportive action would have material fiscal implications for the UAE or the ADGM. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba]

question: If the Regulator is thinking about using Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers to support or fully carry out a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action (and section 27 might require ex-ante judicial approval), what are the reasons it can still say no to recognising the Foreign Resolution Action, in full or in part?
gold_answer: Even if the Regulator’s plan would be to support or fully implement a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action by using one or more Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers (with any applicable ex-ante judicial approval requirement under section 27), it can still refuse to recognise the underlying Foreign Resolution Action, either entirely or only for certain elements. [#TGT:5798f720-7021-4b63-9ebe-f1a30aebee29] The refusal decision is available where the Regulator is satisfied that one or more listed grounds exist. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] These grounds include an adverse impact on financial stability in the ADGM. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] They also include situations where the Resolution Conditions are not met for the relevant entity listed in section 2 in relation to the Regulator’s proposed Resolution Action under section 78(5), or where taking Resolution Action under section 78(5) for an ADGM Branch is not needed to meet one or more Resolution Objectives. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] Another basis is unequal treatment: if creditors located or payable in the ADGM would not receive the same treatment and similar legal rights as creditors (including depositors) located or payable in the relevant non-ADGM jurisdiction, merely because they are in the ADGM. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] The Regulator may also refuse if recognition and supportive action would have material fiscal implications for the UAE or the ADGM. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba]

question: How must an Authorised Person determine the amount of its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital when it has private sector credit exposures in multiple jurisdictions, including how the weighted average of the applicable jurisdictional buffer rates is computed and then applied to the Total Risk Exposure Amount?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must set its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital as a product of (i) its Total Risk Exposure Amount and (ii) a weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates applicable to the jurisdictions where its private sector credit exposures are located. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] The Total Risk Exposure Amount used in this calculation is the Total Risk Exposure Amount calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, and the weighted average rate must be calculated in accordance with the specified rules for determining that weighted average. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] To compute the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates across jurisdictions, the Authorised Person must: (1) for each jurisdiction in which it has private sector credit exposures, take the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction, divide it by the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions, and multiply the result by the applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate in that jurisdiction; and then (2) sum these jurisdiction-level contributions across all jurisdictions. [#TGT:e71f9d6c-0033-443d-9ce0-aa873bdd8124] The resulting weighted average rate is then multiplied by the Total Risk Exposure Amount to yield the required Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]

question: If an Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures in more than one jurisdiction, what steps does it follow to work out the weighted average Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate and then calculate the Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures in multiple jurisdictions, it must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by multiplying its Total Risk Exposure Amount by a weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply in the jurisdictions where those exposures are located. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] The Total Risk Exposure Amount used for this purpose is the Total Risk Exposure Amount calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, and the weighted average rate must be determined using the prescribed method for jurisdictional weighting. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] The weighted average rate is built up jurisdiction by jurisdiction. For each jurisdiction where the Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures, it must calculate that jurisdiction’s contribution by taking the Total Risk Exposure Amount related to private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction, dividing it by the Total Risk Exposure Amount related to the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions, and multiplying by the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate applicable in that jurisdiction. [#TGT:e71f9d6c-0033-443d-9ce0-aa873bdd8124] It must then add together all of those jurisdiction contributions to get the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates. [#TGT:e71f9d6c-0033-443d-9ce0-aa873bdd8124] Finally, it applies that weighted average rate to the Total Risk Exposure Amount to arrive at the Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]

question: Where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person and the parties have a written agreement disapplying Rule 19.21.5 (liability for charges) and/or setting a different time period for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 19.17.1, how should the Payment Service Provider’s liability to the Payment Service User for charges and interest arising from non-execution, defective, or late execution of a Payment Transaction be treated?
gold_answer: Even where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person and the parties have agreed in writing that certain listed Rules do not apply (including Rule 19.21.5 on liability for charges) and/or have agreed a different time period for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 19.17.1, the Payment Service Provider’s liability described in the TARGET provision remains a defined liability statement for charges and interest consequences of execution failures. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] Specifically, the TARGET text states that a Payment Service Provider is liable to its Payment Service User for (i) any charges for which the Payment Service User is responsible and (ii) any interest the Payment Service User must pay, where those amounts arise as a consequence of the Payment Service Provider’s non-execution, defective execution, or late execution of a Payment Transaction. [#TGT:7a0dd0a5-6eb8-41ba-8900-b4048ce180fa] The SOURCE text is relevant to scope because it permits, for non-Natural Person users, a written agreement to switch off enumerated Rules (including Rule 19.21.5) and to alter the time period tied to unauthorised or incorrectly executed transactions for Rule 19.17.1 purposes. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] Accordingly, when assessing liability for charges and interest in the execution-failure scenarios described in TARGET, you must also check whether the parties have exercised the SOURCE option to disapply Rule 19.21.5 and/or adjust the Rule 19.17.1 time period, because those contractual choices affect which listed Rules govern alongside the TARGET liability statement. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] [#TGT:7a0dd0a5-6eb8-41ba-8900-b4048ce180fa]

question: If the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, and the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider have a written deal saying Rule 19.21.5 (liability for charges) does not apply, who is responsible for charges and interest when a Payment Transaction is not executed, is executed badly, or is executed late?
gold_answer: For a Payment Service User that is not a Natural Person, the SOURCE text allows the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider to agree in writing that certain specified Rules do not apply, including Rule 19.21.5 on liability for charges. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] Separately, the TARGET text sets out a liability position tied to execution problems: it says the Payment Service Provider is liable to its Payment Service User for any charges the Payment Service User is responsible for, and any interest the Payment Service User must pay, when those amounts arise because the Payment Service Provider did not execute the Payment Transaction, executed it defectively, or executed it late. [#TGT:7a0dd0a5-6eb8-41ba-8900-b4048ce180fa] To answer “who pays” in your scenario, you must use both passages: the SOURCE establishes that (because the user is not a Natural Person) the parties can contractually switch off Rule 19.21.5, while the TARGET provides the concrete statement that, in non-execution/defective/late execution cases, the Payment Service Provider bears liability to the Payment Service User for the relevant charges and interest consequences. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] [#TGT:7a0dd0a5-6eb8-41ba-8900-b4048ce180fa] In practice, you would confirm whether the written agreement actually disapplies Rule 19.21.5 (as permitted by SOURCE) and then apply the TARGET liability statement to the execution-failure facts described. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] [#TGT:7a0dd0a5-6eb8-41ba-8900-b4048ce180fa]

question: When an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, how must it determine the maximum distributable amount (including the profit base and the applicable quartile factor), and what specific actions must it refrain from taking until it has both calculated that amount and notified the Regulator?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must calculate a maximum distributable amount and then use that calculation as a gating condition before taking certain capital- and remuneration-related actions. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] The maximum distributable amount is determined by multiplying (i) a defined profit sum by (ii) a factor that depends on where the Authorised Person’s CET1 Capital (that is not used to meet the Capital Requirement, including any Individual Capital Requirement) falls within the Combined Buffer Requirement quartiles. [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] The profit sum is the total of interim or year-end profits that were not included in CET1 Capital and that accrued after the most recent distribution of profits and after any actions referenced in Rule 3.19.3(b). [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] The applicable factor is 0 in the first quartile, 0.2 in the second, 0.4 in the third, and 0.6 in the fourth. [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] Until it has calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator, it must not: (a) make a distribution connected with CET1 Capital; (b) create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits; (c) pay variable remuneration where the obligation was created when it failed to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement; or (d) make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]

question: If an Authorised Person is below its Combined Buffer Requirement, what steps does it have to take to work out the maximum distributable amount (what profits to use and what quartile factor applies), and what must it avoid doing until it has done the calculation and notified the Regulator?
gold_answer: When an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must first calculate its maximum distributable amount and treat that calculation (plus notifying the Regulator) as a prerequisite before it carries out certain distributions, remuneration steps, or capital-instrument payments. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] To calculate the maximum distributable amount, it multiplies a specific profit total by a factor tied to the quartile position of its CET1 Capital that is not used to meet the Capital Requirement (including any Individual Capital Requirement). [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] The profit total is limited to interim or year-end profits that were excluded from CET1 Capital and that built up after the most recent profit distribution and after any actions referred to in Rule 3.19.3(b). [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] The factor is set by quartile: 0 (first), 0.2 (second), 0.4 (third), or 0.6 (fourth). [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] Until it has calculated the amount and notified the Regulator, it must not make CET1-related distributions, create obligations for variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, pay variable remuneration where the obligation arose while it was failing the buffer, or make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]

question: When a Payment Order for a single Payment Transaction is sent using a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, how should the Payment Service Provider determine which post‑initiation disclosures it must still provide immediately after initiation versus which general information it may omit because another Payment Service Provider has provided or will provide it under Section 19.2 for the Framework Contract?
gold_answer: For a Payment Order transmitted via a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider for that single Payment Transaction may omit only the “general information” that would otherwise be required under Rule 19.5.1, but only to the extent that such general information has been provided or will be provided under Section 19.2 by another Payment Service Provider in respect of the Framework Contract. [#SRC:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2] However, immediately after the initiation of the Payment Order, the Payment Service Provider must still provide or make available the specific post‑initiation items listed (to the Payer and, where applicable, the Payee), because these are the required immediate confirmations and transaction details rather than the general information covered by the Framework Contract disclosure.
