[#TGT:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622] In practice, this means the provider should ensure delivery of: confirmation that initiation was successful with the Payer’s Payment Service Provider; a reference to identify the Payment Transaction (including Payer/Payee and any transferred information where appropriate); the transaction amount and currency; any charges and any applicable breakdown; any exchange rate used (or a reference) and the post‑conversion amount; the date the Payment Order was received; and the Credit Value Date. [#TGT:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622] The omission is limited to the general information already handled under Section 19.2 for the Framework Contract by another Payment Service Provider, and does not displace these immediate post‑initiation disclosures. [#SRC:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2]

question: When a Relevant Person proposes to rely on a Person in (1) for elements of CDD, how must it determine and evidence that the third party is regulated in a country with AML/TFS rules equivalent to FATF standards, and what immediate CDD-information and document-availability steps must be taken as part of that reliance?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person may rely on a Person in (1) for relevant elements of CDD only if it both (i) meets the operational conditions for third-party reliance and (ii) is satisfied that the third party is regulated and supervised in a country whose AML/TFS regulations are equivalent to FATF standards. [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275] To support the equivalence determination, the Relevant Person must take into account a range of jurisdictional indicators, including published mutual evaluations or assessment/follow-up reports by bodies such as FATF, the IMF, the World Bank, the OECD or other International Organisations, as well as whether the jurisdiction is a member of FATF or regional groups (e.g., MENAFATF or the Gulf Co-operation Council). [#SRC:06794d47-81ee-49d0-bf3a-58e87a031da4] It must also consider contextual risk factors like political stability and corruption levels, and any recent criticism (including FATF advisory notices or public assessments by the listed organisations, or reports from relevant NGOs or specialist commercial organisations). [#SRC:06794d47-81ee-49d0-bf3a-58e87a031da4] In parallel, it must immediately obtain the necessary CDD information from the third party and take adequate steps to ensure certified copies of the documents used for the relied-on CDD elements will be available on request without delay. [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275] Finally, it must confirm the third party did not use an exception for any CDD element being relied on and that any information relied on is up to date. [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275]

question: If the Customer is not a Natural Person, what can the Customer and the Third Party Provider agree to change in writing about which Rules apply (and timing for unauthorised/incorrectly executed Payment Transactions), and what does the Third Party Provider still owe the Customer if a Third Party Transaction is not done, done badly, or done late?
gold_answer: When the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider may make a written agreement that switches off only certain named Rules, and they may also agree a different time period for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 20.10.1. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] The Rules that can be disapplied by that written agreement are limited to the specific list provided (covering charges for information, withdrawal of consent, revocation of a Payment Order, requests for refund, evidence on authentication and execution, and liability for charges). [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] Even with such an agreement in place, the Third Party Provider remains liable to its Customer for the financial impact described where the Third Party Provider does not execute a Third Party Transaction, or executes it defectively or late. [#TGT:e704735d-e9c8-4326-b79a-28e066317151] That liability is framed as covering any charges for which the Customer is responsible and any interest the Customer must pay, but only where those amounts arise as a consequence of the Third Party Provider’s non-execution, defective execution, or late execution of the Third Party Transaction. [#TGT:e704735d-e9c8-4326-b79a-28e066317151] Accordingly, the written agreement can adjust the listed Rule-based protections and timing, but it does not remove the stated responsibility for charges and interest caused by execution failures. [#TGT:e704735d-e9c8-4326-b79a-28e066317151]

question: An Issuer plans to admit its Securities to trading on a MTF and wants to run a single fundraising that includes (i) an offer to no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients and (ii) a parallel offer to Professional Clients. Under the described framework, how can the Issuer structure this as Exempt Offers, and what specific Exempt Offer circumstance is not available when relying on additional circumstances alongside the 200-Person MTF route?
gold_answer: The Issuer can structure the fundraising as simultaneous Exempt Offers by combining the specific 200-Person route tied to admission to trading on a MTF with a separate Exempt Offer directed at Professional Clients. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] The 200-Person limb is available where an Exempt Offer is directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients and the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] In parallel, the Issuer may make an Exempt Offer to (or directed at only) Professional Clients, which is a prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] When the Issuer is seeking admission to trading on an MTF using the 200-Person route, it may also rely on one or more other Exempt Offer circumstances, but it cannot rely on the circumstance corresponding to MKT Rule 4.3.1(2). [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] This means the combined structure can use the 200-Person MTF-based Exempt Offer plus the Professional Client-only Exempt Offer, while excluding the specific additional circumstance that is carved out. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange wants to admit Units in a closed-ended Investment Fund to trading, what must its Business Rules achieve, and what closed-ended fund checks should it use to decide whether trading will be fair, orderly and efficient?
gold_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange can admit Financial Instruments to trading only if its Business Rules ensure that instruments admitted to trading are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] For Units in a closed-ended Investment Fund, the way it should judge whether that “fair, orderly and efficient” standard is met is by taking into account two specific fund features: how widely the Units are distributed to the public, and whether the value of the Units is made sufficiently transparent to investors. [#SRC:72e47a23-5aa5-4df1-a4d6-2aaf037e9131] The value-transparency element can be satisfied, for this assessment, either through publication of information about the Fund’s investment strategy or through periodic publication of a net asset value. [#SRC:72e47a23-5aa5-4df1-a4d6-2aaf037e9131] Accordingly, the Business Rules should not just state the general trading-quality requirement; they should be applied through an admission review that explicitly checks those closed-ended fund factors so the Recognised Investment Exchange can conclude the Units will trade fairly, orderly and efficiently on its market. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]

question: When an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM and therefore has an obligation to publish a Prospectus under Section 61 of FSMR, what consequence described in the Regulations may apply if the person making the Prospectus Offer fails to publish information they are required to publish, and how is that information published?
gold_answer: For an Issuer making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, the offer is within the regime where publishing a Prospectus is an identified obligation (including under Section 61 of FSMR). [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] If, in that Prospectus Offer context, the person making the Prospectus Offer does not publish information that they are required to publish by or under the Regulations, the Regulator has a discretionary power to step in and publish the missing required information. [#TGT:cd1d6043-c316-4559-ad75-ad86cdaeaa9f] The mechanism for that intervention is that the Regulator may publish the information using the manner that is prescribed in the Rules, rather than leaving publication solely to the person making the Prospectus Offer. [#TGT:cd1d6043-c316-4559-ad75-ad86cdaeaa9f] This consequence is relevant to the Issuer’s ADGM public offer scenario because the Prospectus publication obligation is part of the requirements applicable to such Offers of Securities (including those under Sections 58 to 71 of FSMR and Chapter 4 of the Markets Rules ("MKT")), and a failure to publish required information can therefore trigger the Regulator’s publication power. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]

question: Where an Issuer is seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF and intends to rely on the Exempt Offer circumstance that permits an Offer to no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients, can the Issuer simultaneously structure the same fundraising as an Exempt Offer to an unlimited number of Professional Clients, and what limitation applies to which Exempt Offer circumstances may be combined?
gold_answer: Yes. An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF may run a simultaneous Exempt Offer that (i) is directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients and (ii) is also directed to an unlimited number of Professional Clients, provided the Issuer is relying on the relevant Exempt Offer circumstances in combination as permitted. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] The “200 Persons” limb corresponds to the prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance for an Offer in or from the ADGM directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients (and not Market Counterparties), where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] The “unlimited Professional Clients” limb aligns with the prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance for an Offer made to or directed at only Professional Clients. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] When combining Exempt Offer circumstances for this MTF admission scenario, the Issuer may rely on one or more of the circumstances within the relevant Exempt Offer rule set, but it cannot use the circumstance identified as MKT Rule 4.3.1(2) as part of that combination. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]

question: If an Issuer wants its Securities admitted to trading on an MTF and plans an Exempt Offer to up to 200 people who are not Professional Clients, what extra condition about the offer channel must be met, and can the Issuer also offer to Professional Clients at the same time?
gold_answer: For the “up to 200” route, the offer must fit the circumstance where an Offer in or from the ADGM is directed at no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients (and not Market Counterparties) and the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] In the MTF admission context described, an Issuer can also run a simultaneous Exempt Offer to an unlimited number of Professional Clients alongside the offer to up to 200 non‑Professional Clients. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] The Professional Client leg is consistent with the prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance for an Offer made to or directed at only Professional Clients. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] When structuring the combined approach for admission to trading on an MTF, the Issuer may rely on one or more Exempt Offer circumstances, but there is a specific carve-out: the circumstance identified as MKT Rule 4.3.1(2) cannot be used as part of that combination. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]

question: How should an Authorised Person determine whether it falls into Category 1 or Category 3C when its Financial Services Permission includes managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account, and what specific PSIA type and additional determinative authorisations should be checked to avoid misclassification?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person should classify itself by identifying which specific Profit Sharing Investment Account (PSIA) permission it holds and then applying the category-specific determinative authorisation tests. If its Financial Services Permission authorises Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, that authorisation is determinative for Category 1 (provided it does not meet the criteria of Category 5). [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] By contrast, Category 3C is tied to authorisation for Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAr (and/or certain other listed activities), and also requires that the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5. [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0] Practically, the firm should: (i) confirm whether the PSIA permission is PSIAu or PSIAr; (ii) check whether it is authorised for Accepting Deposits (which would also be determinative for Category 1); and (iii) if considering Category 3C, verify whether it is authorised for any of the other Category 3C activities (e.g., Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody other than for a Fund, Providing Trust Services as trustee of at least one express trust, or Providing Money Services). [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0] The classification should follow the determinative authorisation identified for the relevant category rather than other additional Regulated Activities the firm may also be permitted to conduct. [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]

question: When an Authorised Person recognises the effect of eligible financial Collateral, how must it choose between the Financial Collateral Simplified Approach (FCSA) and the Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA), and if it uses the FCCA, what instruments qualify as eligible financial Collateral (including any conditions for Units in a Collective Investment Fund)?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral by applying one of two specified approaches: the Financial Collateral Simplified Approach (FCSA) or the Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA). [#SRC:f161ce59-6314-4980-8eaf-752bb38a5a19] If the Authorised Person elects to use the FCCA, the set of eligible financial Collateral includes (i) any instrument that is listed in Rule 4.13.5, (ii) any equity Security (expressly including a convertible bond) provided it is traded on a regulated exchange, and (iii) any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund that invests in those regulated-exchange-traded equity Securities. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] For Units in a Collective Investment Fund to be eligible under the FCCA, two conditions must be met: the Unit price must be publicly quoted on a daily basis, and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property must be invested in instruments that are listed in the FCCA rule and in Rule 4.13.5. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] This FCCA eligibility scope operates within the broader requirement that the Authorised Person use either FCSA (which adopts the treatment under Rule 4.13.5 for collateral composition) or FCCA (which adopts the treatment under Rule 4.13.6) to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral. [#SRC:f161ce59-6314-4980-8eaf-752bb38a5a19]

question: Where an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in accordance with Rule 20.7 and it leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction, what refunds must the Third Party Provider make (including how amounts are netted between the Primary Financial Institution and the Customer), and by when must the refund be provided once the Third Party Provider has confirmed the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed?
gold_answer: In the scenario where an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in accordance with Rule 20.7 and it results in an unauthorised Payment Transaction, the Third Party Provider has a dual refund obligation that allocates amounts between the Primary Financial Institution and the Customer, and it must also meet a specific timing standard once it has confirmed the issue. [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe] Specifically, the Third Party Provider must (a) reimburse the Primary Financial Institution for the amount the Primary Financial Institution may already have repaid to the Customer, and (b) reimburse the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, reduced by any amount the Third Party Provider has already reimbursed to the Primary Financial Institution (so the Customer is not paid twice for the same loss). [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe] Once the Third Party Provider has confirmed that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, it must provide the refund as soon as practicable and, at the latest, by the end of the day after the day of that confirmation. [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] This timing requirement applies to the refund obligation described, ensuring prompt remediation after confirmation. [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]

question: If a Third Party Transaction wasn’t authorised under Rule 20.7 and it causes an unauthorised Payment Transaction, who does the Third Party Provider have to pay back (and how do you avoid paying the same amount twice), and what is the latest deadline after the Third Party Provider confirms the transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed?
gold_answer: When an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in line with Rule 20.7 and it leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction, the Third Party Provider must make refunds to both the Primary Financial Institution and the Customer, with an offset to prevent double recovery. [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe] The Third Party Provider must refund the Primary Financial Institution for any amount the Primary Financial Institution may already have refunded to the Customer. [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe] It must also refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, but it can subtract (i.e., pay “less”) any amount it has already refunded to the Primary Financial Institution, so the Customer is not effectively reimbursed twice for the same unauthorised amount. [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe] After the Third Party Provider has confirmed that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, it must provide the refund promptly and no later than the end of the day following the day of that confirmation. [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] This creates a clear latest cut-off tied to the confirmation date, rather than the original execution date. [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]

question: When an Authorised Person that has its registered head office in ADGM applies to the Regulator for approval to establish a branch outside ADGM, what fee basis applies to the application, and in what circumstance may the Regulator additionally impose a supplementary fee linked to the destination jurisdiction’s regulatory cooperation arrangements?
gold_answer: For an application by an Authorised Person that has its registered head office in ADGM to establish a branch outside ADGM, the applicant must pay an application fee calculated as 50% of the highest application fee in Chapter 3 for the Regulated Activities it proposes to carry on from that branch. [#TGT:363c3cff-9b23-461e-a521-d56d8c16221f] In addition to that application-fee basis, the Regulator may also charge a supplementary fee where the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction in which there is not an adequate memorandum of understanding between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator for that jurisdiction. [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92] Practically, this means the fee outcome has two components: (i) a mandatory application fee tied to the highest Chapter 3 fee applicable to the Regulated Activities intended to be undertaken from the branch, and (ii) a potential extra charge that depends on whether the destination jurisdiction has adequate regulatory cooperation arrangements in place with the Regulator. [#TGT:363c3cff-9b23-461e-a521-d56d8c16221f] [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92] The supplementary fee is not automatic; it is triggered by the absence of an adequate memorandum of understanding with the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in the jurisdiction where the branch would operate. [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92]

question: Where a Passported Fund remains materially prejudicial in ADGM despite measures taken by a Home Regulator, how does the Regulator’s ability to request urgent discussions with that Home Regulator connect to the Regulator’s subsequent power to take protective measures if those urgent discussions do not resolve the issues within a reasonable period?
gold_answer: In the Passported Fund context, if a Home Regulator has already taken measures (if any) but the Fund Manager’s activities in ADGM (or those of its Agent or any other Licensed Person promoting the Passported Fund) continue to be materially prejudicial to Unitholders situated in ADGM or to ADGM’s financial stability or integrity, the Regulator may initiate the process by requesting urgent discussions with the Home Regulator responsible for supervision and enforcement of the Passported Fund. [#TGT:722d2090-eec8-4ae1-8d98-db9a10f13e55] If those urgent discussions (as referenced in Rule 9.5.2) do not resolve the issues to the Regulator’s satisfaction within a period that is reasonable in the circumstances, the Regulator may then escalate by taking all appropriate measures needed to protect the interests of Unitholders domiciled in ADGM or to protect the financial stability and integrity of the ADGM market. [#SRC:6a79069b-b2b7-4349-9fa6-ae21f98b3a02] This linkage means the “urgent discussions” step functions as a precursor mechanism in the scenario where prejudice persists despite Home Regulator action, and the trigger for further intervention is the failure of those discussions to achieve a satisfactory resolution within a reasonable timeframe. [#TGT:722d2090-eec8-4ae1-8d98-db9a10f13e55] [#SRC:6a79069b-b2b7-4349-9fa6-ae21f98b3a02]

question: If a Home Regulator has already taken steps about a Passported Fund but the Fund Manager (or its Agent or another Licensed Person promoting it) is still causing serious harm in ADGM, what happens next—first with urgent discussions and then if those talks don’t fix the problem in a reasonable time?
gold_answer: When a Passported Fund situation in ADGM remains materially prejudicial even after measures (if any) taken by the Home Regulator, the Regulator can respond by asking for urgent discussions with the Home Regulator that has supervision and enforcement responsibility for the Passported Fund. [#TGT:722d2090-eec8-4ae1-8d98-db9a10f13e55] The prejudice that can trigger this includes harm to Unitholders of the Passported Fund who are situated in ADGM, or harm to ADGM’s financial stability or integrity. [#TGT:722d2090-eec8-4ae1-8d98-db9a10f13e55] If those urgent discussions (the ones referred to in Rule 9.5.2) do not settle the issues to the Regulator’s satisfaction within a period that is reasonable in the circumstances, the Regulator is not limited to continued dialogue and may take all appropriate measures needed to protect Unitholders domiciled in ADGM or to safeguard the financial stability and integrity of the ADGM market. [#SRC:6a79069b-b2b7-4349-9fa6-ae21f98b3a02] In practical terms, the sequence is: persistent material prejudice despite Home Regulator measures leads to urgent discussions, and an unresolved outcome within a reasonable time opens the door to protective measures by the Regulator. [#TGT:722d2090-eec8-4ae1-8d98-db9a10f13e55] [#SRC:6a79069b-b2b7-4349-9fa6-ae21f98b3a02]

question: When applying the 20% cap formula for a Listed Entity’s proposed issue or agreement to issue Equity Securities, how must the entity count Convertible Securities and partly paid Securities when determining the number of Equity Securities for the “Relevant Issues” subtraction, and how does that counting interact with the requirement for approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number produced by the formula (20% × Base Amount) minus Relevant Issues unless it has approval from the holders of Ordinary Securities. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] To apply that formula correctly, the entity must calculate the number of Equity Securities it is issuing or agreeing to issue (including those that contribute to “Relevant Issues”) using the specified counting rules, unless the Regulator determines otherwise. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f] In that calculation, each partly paid Security is counted as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities into which it can be paid up, and each Convertible Security is counted as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities into which it can be converted. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f] Those counted amounts then feed into the “Relevant Issues” figure, which is defined as Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months, excluding those done with holder approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5 or under an exception in Rule 9.7.4. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Accordingly, the counting method determines the size of the subtraction for Relevant Issues and, in turn, whether the proposed issue exceeds the cap and therefore requires holder approval. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]

question: If a Listed Entity is checking whether it needs holders of Ordinary Securities to approve a new issue because of the 20% limit, how should it count partly paid Securities and Convertible Securities when working out the number of Equity Securities for the calculation, including the “Relevant Issues” part?
gold_answer: To decide whether approval from holders of Ordinary Securities is needed, the Listed Entity must compare the proposed issue (or agreement to issue) against the maximum allowed under the formula: (20% × Base Amount) minus Relevant Issues; issuing above that maximum is not permitted without that approval. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] When determining the number of Equity Securities for this purpose (including the amount that contributes to “Relevant Issues”), the entity must apply the counting approach set for new issues unless the Regulator determines otherwise. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f] Under that approach, a partly paid Security is treated as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities it could become if fully paid up, and a Convertible Security is treated as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities it could convert into. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f] Those counted totals are then used when identifying “Relevant Issues,” which covers Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months, but excludes issues made with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5 and issues made under an exception in Rule 9.7.4. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Using these counting rules ensures the cap test reflects potential dilution in fully paid Ordinary Securities terms. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f]

question: When calculating CET1 deductions for investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities under Rule 3.10.7(g) and (h), how should an Authorised Person determine whether to use gross long positions or a net long position approach for Trading Book holdings, and what additional method applies where the Trading Book exposure is indirect via index Securities?
gold_answer: For Rule 3.10.7(g) and (h), an Authorised Person must apply the Trading Book-specific netting methodology described for those holdings, rather than defaulting to a gross-long-only approach for all positions. [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c] The SOURCE establishes that, for Rule 3.10.7(f), (g) and (h), the deductible amount is calculated on the basis of gross long positions (with a stated cross-reference to Rule 3.10.15), which creates the baseline calculation concept that must be reconciled with the TARGET’s Trading Book treatment for (g) and (h). [#SRC:40c66431-d7b0-41ae-bc47-0ae63f4d9454] In practice under (g) and (h), for holdings in the Trading Book, the holdings must be calculated using the net long position in the same underlying Exposure, but only where the short position’s maturity matches the long position’s maturity or the short has a residual maturity of at least one year. [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c] Additionally, where the Trading Book holding is indirect and takes the form of holdings of index Securities, the amount to be deducted must be determined by calculating the underlying Exposure to the capital instruments of the Relevant Entities included in the indices. [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c]

question: If an Authorised Person is working out CET1 deductions for Rule 3.10.7(g) and (h), what position basis should they use (gross long vs net long) for Trading Book holdings, and how do they handle Trading Book holdings that are index Securities?
gold_answer: For Rule 3.10.7(g) and (h), the Trading Book calculation uses a net long position approach in the same underlying Exposure when the maturity condition for the short position is met, and this sits alongside the general concept that deductible holdings are calculated using gross long positions for Rule 3.10.7(f), (g) and (h) (noting the stated cross-reference to Rule 3.10.15). [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c] [#SRC:40c66431-d7b0-41ae-bc47-0ae63f4d9454] Specifically, for holdings in the Trading Book of capital instruments of Relevant Entities, the holdings must be calculated on the basis of the net long position in the same underlying Exposure, provided the short position either matches the long position’s maturity or has a residual maturity of at least one year. [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c] If the Trading Book exposure is indirect and takes the form of holdings of index Securities, the amount to be deducted must be determined by calculating the underlying Exposure to the capital instruments of the Relevant Entities in the indices. [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c] This answers both how to treat direct Trading Book holdings (net long with a maturity test) and how to treat index-based indirect holdings (look-through to underlying Exposure) within the broader gross-long deduction framing. [#SRC:40c66431-d7b0-41ae-bc47-0ae63f4d9454]

question: When a Payment Order for an individual Payment Transaction is transmitted using a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, which post-initiation information must the Payment Service Provider still provide immediately after initiation, and what category of information may it omit because another Payment Service Provider provides it under Section 19.2?
gold_answer: For an individual Payment Transaction sent via a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider must still provide (or make available) the post-initiation, transaction-specific information immediately after the initiation of the Payment Order to the Payer and, where applicable, to the Payee. [#SRC:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622] This includes confirmation that initiation with the Payer’s Payment Service Provider was successful, a reference that lets the Payer and Payee identify the Payment Transaction (including identifying the Payer and Payee and, where appropriate, information transferred with the Payment Order), the transaction amount in the currency used in the Payment Order, any charges payable (and where applicable a breakdown in the Payment Order currency), any exchange-rate details and the post-conversion amount where an exchange rate is used, the date the Payment Service Provider received the Payment Order, and the Credit Value Date. [#SRC:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622] However, in this Framework Contract/Payment Instrument scenario, the Payment Service Provider for that single Payment Transaction does not need to provide the “general information” that would otherwise be required under Rule 19.5.1, to the extent that such general information has been provided or will be provided under Section 19.2 by another Payment Service Provider in respect of the Framework Contract. [#TGT:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2]

question: In what admission-related scenarios would the Regulator generally require a Reporting Entity to complete MKT Form 10-1 quarterly, and how do those scenarios align with the specific triggers that make quarterly completion mandatory?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity must complete MKT Form 10-1 on a quarterly basis when the Regulator requires it, including where that requirement is imposed as a condition of admission to the Official List. [#TGT:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75] The Regulator will generally require this quarterly reporting in admission-related circumstances where the Listed Entity being admitted to the Official List is admitted under the assets eligibility test, has less than three years of audited financial statements, or is otherwise considered to need quarterly cash reporting (including where the admission involves a cash-box). [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8] Read together, these passages indicate that the “condition of admission” trigger for quarterly MKT Form 10-1 completion can be met in practice by the Regulator’s general approach to admissions that present heightened cash-reporting needs—such as assets-test admissions, shorter audited financial history, or cash-box admissions. [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8] [#TGT:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75] Separately, quarterly completion is also mandatory if the Regulator classifies the Reporting Entity as a Mining Exploration Reporting Entity or a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity, or if the Regulator requires it pursuant to section 84 of the FSMR. [#TGT:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75]

question: When an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business is preparing its Resolution Pack, what specific Third Party Agent acknowledgement record must be included if the firm passes, or permits to be passed, Safe Custody Assets to a Third Party Agent, and what minimum content must that acknowledgement cover?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person passes, or permits to be passed, Safe Custody Assets to a Third Party Agent, it must obtain a written acknowledgement from that Third Party Agent, and the relevant acknowledgement record must be included in the Resolution Pack as part of the required records for Client Investments involving a Third Party Agent. [#TGT:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] The acknowledgement must, at a minimum, address operational and safeguarding points, including: the account title must clearly distinguish the account from any account holding Investments belonging to the Authorised Person and be in the form the Authorised Person requests; Client Investment credits/withdrawals must follow the Authorised Person’s instructions; and Client Investments must be held separately from the Third Party Agent’s own assets. [#TGT:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98] It must also set out arrangements for recording/registering Client Investments and handling dividends/entitlements/interest and instructions, require delivery of statements to the Authorised Person (including frequency) detailing Client Investments deposited, and confirm that Investments in the account are held by the Authorised Person as agent with restrictions on combining accounts or asserting charges, liens, set-off, or counterclaims against those Investments for sums owed on other accounts. [#TGT:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98] Finally, the acknowledgement must state the extent of the Third Party Agent’s liability in the event of default, and that written acknowledgement record is part of the Resolution Pack’s Third Party Agent acknowledgement materials for Client Investments. [#TGT:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]

question: What does an Authorised Person’s periodic stress test need to cover for securitisations, if it must also check whether the firm can still do securitisation in the future for CRM or liquidity, and take into account stressed market conditions and pipeline deals that might not close?
gold_answer: The periodic stress test needs to be built so it covers the required securitisation perimeter and also the specific stressed-scenario questions the rules call out. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] First, it must be a periodic stress test that relates to the Authorised Person’s securitisation activities and its off balance sheet Exposures, and it must include testing whether the firm will be able in the future to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] Second, when running those tests, the firm must look at stressed market conditions and assess the firm wide impact of the securitisation activities and Exposures, including what those stresses mean for other sources of risk (not just the securitisation positions themselves). [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97] Third, the test scope must include both existing securitisation Exposures and transactions in the pipeline, because the analysis must reflect the risk that pipeline transactions may not be completed in a stressed market scenario. [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97] Putting these together ensures the test covers current and planned securitisation activity, future execution capacity for CRM/liquidity, and the firm-wide consequences under stress. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97]

question: If you have precise information that isn’t public and it’s about a Reporting Entity or Issuer, how do you decide whether it counts as “Inside Information” for products that are not Commodity Derivatives, especially when it might move the price of a Related Instrument?
gold_answer: You treat it as “Inside Information” only if it meets the full definition for products that are not Commodity Derivatives, including the part about likely price impact. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] First, the information must be of a Precise nature and not generally available. [#SRC:ba7db39b-8edf-4a95-94c3-14bd0ddb9c18] Second, it must relate directly or indirectly either to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments, or to one or more of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities. [#SRC:ba7db39b-8edf-4a95-94c3-14bd0ddb9c18] Third, you must consider whether making it public would be likely to have a significant effect on price. [#SRC:ba7db39b-8edf-4a95-94c3-14bd0ddb9c18] In doing that price test, you do not stop at the main product mentioned: the definition also covers a likely significant effect on the price of Related Instruments (as well as Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, and Accepted Spot Commodities) within the non-Commodity Derivatives scope. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] If any of these elements is missing, the information does not meet the definition. [#SRC:ba7db39b-8edf-4a95-94c3-14bd0ddb9c18]

question: When a law enforcement agency seeks a person’s interview answers taken under section 206(1)(a) for use in criminal proceedings against that same person, how do the Regulator’s notification practice and the Investigator’s disclosure prohibition operate together, including the consent pathway and the law/court-order exception?
gold_answer: In this scenario, disclosure to a law enforcement agency for criminal proceedings against the person is generally blocked unless a specific condition is met, and the person is typically given a chance to respond before disclosure occurs. The Investigator is prohibited from disclosing the person’s statement (i.e., answers to questions asked under a section 206(1)(a) requirement) to any law enforcement agency for that purpose unless the person consents or the Regulator must disclose due to law or a court order. [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff] When the Regulator receives such a request from a law enforcement agency, the Regulator will generally notify the person concerned so the person has an opportunity either to consent to the disclosure or to challenge the request. [#SRC:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951] This notification practice aligns with the consent-based disclosure route described for the Investigator, because the person’s consent is one of the two stated gateways for disclosure. [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff] However, the notification is not expected where disclosure is compelled: the Regulator may be required by law or court order to disclose the statement, and in that case the Regulator may disclose without following the general notification approach. [#SRC:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951] The same law/court-order compulsion is also an express exception to the Investigator’s non-disclosure rule. [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff]

question: If the police ask for someone’s answers from an interview under section 206(1)(a) to use against that person in a criminal case, what usually happens first, and when can the statement still be shared?
gold_answer: The statement is not meant to be handed over for criminal proceedings against the same person unless one of two specific conditions applies, and the person is usually told about the request so they can respond. The Investigator must not disclose a statement made by a person in answer to questions asked under a section 206(1)(a) requirement to any law enforcement agency for that purpose unless the person consents or the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose it. [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff] When the Regulator receives a request from a law enforcement agency for those interview answers for criminal proceedings against the person, the Regulator will generally notify the person concerned. [#SRC:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951] The point of that notice is to give the person a chance either to agree to the disclosure (which would satisfy the consent condition) or to challenge the request. [#SRC:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951] Even without consent, the statement can still be disclosed if the Regulator is required by law or a court order to disclose it, and that same law/court-order situation is also a stated exception to the Investigator’s non-disclosure rule. [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff]

question: When an Authorised Person wants to provide credit to a Related Person on terms more favourable than those offered to Persons who are not Related Persons, what must its Credit Risk policy include to rely on the employee-credit-policy carve-out while still meeting the conflicts/approval-process controls for Related Person transactions?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may only treat more-favourable credit to a Related Person as permissible if it is delivered under an Employee credit policy that is widely available to Employees and is approved by the Authorised Person's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate. [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] To rely on that approach within its Credit Risk policy framework, the policy must also include adequate conflicts-of-interest procedures for the provision and management of credit, including measures to prevent any Person who directly or indirectly benefits from the credit from being involved in granting or managing it. [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496] The employee policy must clearly specify the terms, conditions and limits for providing credit to those Employees, including limits at both individual and aggregate levels, and it must include mechanisms to ensure ongoing compliance. [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] Those mechanisms must include immediate reporting to the Governing Body or its delegate if there is any deviation from, or breach of, the applicable terms, conditions, or procedures so timely and appropriate action can be taken. [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] Separately, where the policy allows Exposures to Related Persons (on no-more-favourable terms), it must require prior written approval by the Governing Body or its delegate for Exposures (and any write-off) exceeding specified amounts or otherwise posing special risks, and it must exclude beneficiaries from the approval process. [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496]

question: If a firm wants to give an Employee (who is a Related Person) better credit terms than non-Related Persons, what does the Credit Risk policy need to say about (1) the kind of employee credit policy it uses and (2) how it keeps conflicted people out of granting, managing, or approving that credit?
gold_answer: To allow better credit terms for a Related Person who is an Employee, the Credit Risk policy must be built around an Employee credit policy that is widely available to Employees of the Authorised Person and has been approved by the Authorised Person's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate. [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] That employee policy must clearly describe the terms, conditions and limits for providing credit to those Employees, including limits at both individual and aggregate levels, and it must include mechanisms to ensure ongoing compliance. [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] Those mechanisms must include immediate reporting to the Governing Body or its delegate if there is any deviation from or breach of the relevant terms, conditions, or procedures so action can be taken promptly. [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] In parallel, the Credit Risk policy must include conflicts-of-interest procedures for granting and managing credit that prevent any Person who directly or indirectly benefits from the credit from taking part in the process of granting or managing it. [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496] Where the policy requires Governing Body (or delegate) approval for certain Related Person Exposures or write-offs, it must also exclude beneficiaries from the approval process. [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496]

question: For Derivatives (including written credit protection), how should a firm reconcile the SOURCE requirement to compute an Exposure value using an IFRS on-balance sheet amount plus an add-on for potential future Exposure with the TARGET SA-CCR requirement to calculate EAD per netting set using alpha, replacement cost (RC), and potential future exposure (PFE)?
gold_answer: For Derivatives (including written credit protection), the Exposure value framework in the SOURCE is built from two components: (i) an on-balance sheet amount determined under IFRS and (ii) an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated under specified App 4 rules. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] When the firm is applying the SA-CCR method described in the TARGET, it must calculate EAD separately for each netting set and determine it using the formula EAD = alpha * (RC + PFE), with alpha fixed at 1.4. [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] To reconcile the two, the firm should treat the TARGET’s PFE term as the structured “add-on for potential future Exposure” concept referenced in the SOURCE, because both are explicitly defined as potential future exposure amounts calculated under App 4 rule references. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] In addition, the TARGET requires RC (replacement cost) to be calculated under its specified rule set and combined with PFE before applying alpha, and this netting-set-by-netting-set EAD calculation provides the SA-CCR-specific way to operationalize the Exposure measurement for derivatives alongside the SOURCE’s IFRS-plus-add-on structure. [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007]

question: If you are working out exposure for Derivatives (including written credit protection), what are the pieces you need from the SOURCE (IFRS amount plus add-on) and how does the TARGET say to combine RC and PFE (with alpha) for each netting set?
gold_answer: For Derivatives (including written credit protection), the SOURCE says the Exposure value is made up of two parts: the on-balance sheet value measured under IFRS, plus an add-on for potential future Exposure that is calculated using the referenced App 4 rules. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] The TARGET then gives a specific SA-CCR calculation that must be done separately for each netting set, which is important because it sets the unit of calculation (netting set) rather than a single portfolio-wide number. [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] Under SA-CCR, EAD is computed as EAD = alpha * (RC + PFE), where alpha is 1.4, RC is replacement cost calculated under the specified rules, and PFE is the potential future exposure amount calculated under the specified rule. [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] Linking the two passages, the “add-on for potential future Exposure” concept in the SOURCE aligns with the TARGET’s PFE component, because both are explicitly framed as potential future exposure amounts determined by referenced App 4 rule calculations. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] Practically, you would identify the IFRS on-balance sheet amount per the SOURCE and then use the TARGET’s netting-set SA-CCR structure (RC and PFE with alpha) to express the exposure measurement in the SA-CCR form. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918]

question: When an Authorised Person is considering recognising the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative where the protection provider is an MDB, how does the eligibility condition for recognising CRM interact with the requirement to risk weight a CR Exposure in the MDB asset class, including the applicable risk weights by Credit Quality Grade and for unrated exposures?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may recognise the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative provided by an MDB only where the MDB is one of the MDBs referred to in Rules 4.12.7 to 4.12.9, so the protection provider must fall within that MDB category for CRM recognition to be available. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] Separately, where the exposure is a CR Exposure in the MDB asset class, the Authorised Person must apply the MDB asset class risk-weighting table (noting it is stated to be subject to Rules 4.12.8 and 4.12.9). [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c] In practice, this means you address two linked determinations: (i) whether the protection provider qualifies as an MDB for purposes of recognising CRM effects, and (ii) how the relevant CR Exposure in the MDB asset class is risk weighted under the table. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c] Under the table, Credit Quality Grade 1 receives a 0% risk weight; Grades 2 and 3 receive 50%; Grades 4 and 5 receive 100%; Grade 6 receives 150%; and unrated exposures receive 50%. [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c]

question: If the protection seller on a credit derivative is an MDB, what do you need to check so you can count the credit risk mitigation, and what risk weights apply to an MDB asset class CR Exposure by Credit Quality Grade (including unrated)?
gold_answer: To be able to recognise the effects of CRM from a Credit Derivative where the protection provider is an MDB, the Authorised Person must ensure the provider is an MDB of the type referenced in Rules 4.12.7 to 4.12.9, because CRM recognition is only allowed when the provider is one of the listed eligible entity types (including those MDBs). [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] In parallel, if the exposure being assessed is a CR Exposure in the MDB asset class, the Authorised Person must risk weight that exposure using the MDB asset class table (and the table is stated to operate subject to Rules 4.12.8 and 4.12.9). [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c] So you combine an eligibility check (is the protection provider an MDB within the referenced rule set) with the required risk-weighting approach for MDB asset class exposures. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c] The table assigns: 0% for Credit Quality Grade 1; 50% for Grades 2 and 3; 100% for Grades 4 and 5; 150% for Grade 6; and 50% for unrated exposures. [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c]

question: When calculating the Exposure value for on-balance sheet Derivatives (including written credit protection), how should the firm incorporate the potential future Exposure add-on, and how does that interact with the SA-CCR requirement to calculate RC and PFE differently for margined versus unmargined netting sets, including the cap on EAD for margined netting sets?
gold_answer: For on-balance sheet Derivatives (including written credit protection), the Exposure value is determined by combining two elements: the on-balance sheet value measured under IFRS and an additional amount for potential future Exposure that is calculated under the specified App 4 rules. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] When the derivative exposures are being assessed under SA-CCR, the firm must ensure that the replacement cost (RC) and potential future exposure (PFE) components are computed using different methods depending on whether the relevant netting set is margined or unmargined, so the PFE concept used for the add-on must be aligned to the appropriate margined/unmargined treatment. [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941] In addition, where the firm determines an exposure at default (EAD) for a margined netting set, it must apply the cap that limits that margined EAD to no more than the EAD that would result if the same netting set were calculated on an unmargined basis. [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941] Practically, this means the IFRS on-balance sheet value remains part of the Exposure value, while the potential future Exposure add-on is calculated per the referenced rules and then reflected consistently with the SA-CCR margined/unmargined netting set framework and the EAD cap. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941]

question: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity files SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports every year, does it still need to put the MKT Form 12-1 table in its Summary of Reserves and Resources, and does the “dated no earlier than one month before disclosure” rule still matter?
gold_answer: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC, it is not required to comply with Rule 12.14.1. [#SRC:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1] However, the Summary of Reserves and Resources requirement separately says that, subject to Rule 12.14.3, a Petroleum Reporting Entity must include a table in the form of MKT Form 12-1, and that table must be prepared as of a date that is no earlier than one month before the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed. [#TGT:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] Putting these together, the SEC annual filing status only tells you that Rule 12.14.1 does not apply to that entity; it does not, by itself, remove the obligation described for the Summary of Reserves and Resources. [#SRC:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1] [#TGT:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] So, based only on these passages, the entity should still plan to include the MKT Form 12-1 table and ensure the “no earlier than one month prior” dating condition is met when it discloses the Summary of Reserves and Resources, unless Rule 12.14.3 changes that outcome. [#TGT:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04]

question: Where a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a compliant disclosure of Non-Equivalent Estimates, under what conditions may a later disclosure omit the detailed items normally required for material Non-Equivalent Estimates (such as source/date, reliability, and the Competent Person statement), and what specific statement must still be included in the later disclosure?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may omit the detailed information otherwise required for a disclosure of material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation only if the later disclosure is structured as a true follow-on to an earlier disclosure that already met those detailed requirements. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] To do so, the later disclosure must (i) point back to the earlier compliant disclosure, and (ii) include the Mining Reporting Entity’s confirmation that the earlier information still applies and that there is no new material information or data affecting either how the Non-Equivalent Estimates should be relied on/interpreted or the Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] Even when relying on that omission pathway, the later disclosure must still carry an at least equally prominent and proximate statement about the Non-Equivalent Estimates that addresses the same core matters as the required prominent/proximate warning for Non-Equivalent Estimates (i.e., that they are not reported under a Mining Reporting Standard, have not been sufficiently worked by a Competent Person for classification, and may never become reportable as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves). [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity is updating the market again about the same Non-Equivalent Estimates, when can it avoid repeating the long list of details (like the source and date, reliability, and what work is needed to verify them), and what must it say and do instead?
gold_answer: The Mining Reporting Entity can avoid repeating the full set of detailed disclosure items for material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation only when the new announcement is clearly tied to an earlier announcement that already included those items. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] In that situation, the later disclosure must refer readers to the earlier compliant disclosure and must include the Mining Reporting Entity’s confirmation that (a) the earlier information still applies and (b) there is no new material information or data that changes the reliability/interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates or affects the Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] The later disclosure still needs a prominent and nearby warning statement about the Non-Equivalent Estimates, and it must be at least as prominent and proximate as the earlier required warning. [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] That warning must cover the key points that the estimates are Non-Equivalent Estimates not disclosed under a Mining Reporting Standard, that a Competent Person has not done enough work to classify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, and that it is uncertain they will ever be reportable as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves after further work. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]

question: For unauthorised Third Party Transactions, when is a Third Party Provider required to provide a refund, and how does the position change if the Third Party Provider has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer?
gold_answer: For an unauthorised (or incorrectly executed) Third Party Transaction, the Third Party Provider is required to provide a refund under Rule 20.12.1 promptly: it must do so as soon as practicable and, at the latest, by the end of the day after the day it confirms the transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed. [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] This timing obligation is framed around the point of confirmation, so the operational trigger for the deadline is the Third Party Provider’s confirmation that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed. [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] However, the specific requirement to provide a refund within the timeframe prescribed in Rule 20.12.2 is disapplied where the Third Party Provider has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer. [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012] In practice, this means that even though refunds are generally expected quickly once unauthorised status is confirmed, the Third Party Provider is not bound by the Rule 20.12.2 timeframe in the fraud-suspicion scenario described. [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012] The analysis therefore turns on (i) confirmation of unauthorised/incorrect execution for the standard deadline, and (ii) whether there are reasonable grounds to suspect Customer fraud for the Rule 20.12.2 timing carve-out. [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012]

question: If a Third Party Provider confirms a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, how quickly must it refund, and what happens to the refund timing rule if it reasonably suspects the Customer is acting fraudulently?
gold_answer: Once the Third Party Provider has confirmed that a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, it must provide a refund under Rule 20.12.1 as soon as practicable and no later than the end of the next day (the day after the confirmation day). [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] The key timing point is the Third Party Provider’s confirmation, because the “next-day” deadline is measured from that day. [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] There is also a specific exception tied to suspected fraud: the requirement to provide a refund within the timeframe set by Rule 20.12.2 does not apply if the Third Party Provider has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer. [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012] Put together, the general rule is a fast refund once unauthorised/incorrect execution is confirmed, but the Third Party Provider is not required to follow the Rule 20.12.2 timeframe when it has reasonable grounds for that fraud suspicion. [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012] This means your compliance check should identify (1) the confirmation date for the unauthorised/incorrect execution finding and (2) whether the fraud-suspicion condition is met, because that condition changes whether the Rule 20.12.2 timing requirement applies. [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012]

question: When calculating CET1 Capital deductions for holdings of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities, how should an Authorised Person determine whether the holding is treated as a “significant investment” (thereby falling under the deduction category for significant investments rather than the category for non-significant investments), and what types of deductions are required to be taken from CET1 Capital in that calculation?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must first classify its holdings of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities by determining whether the holding constitutes a “significant investment,” because the CET1 deduction category differs depending on that classification. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] A holding is treated as a significant investment if any of the specified conditions are met: the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by the Relevant Entity; or the Authorised Person has Close Links with the entity and owns its CET1 Capital instruments; or the Authorised Person owns the entity’s CET1 Capital instruments and the entity is not included in consolidation under Chapter 8 but is included in the same accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for IFRS financial reporting. [#SRC:c9f19d0b-d036-4cfe-88ba-7e2528a70c11] Once classified, the Authorised Person must deduct from the calculation of its CET1 Capital the applicable amount of direct and indirect holdings in Relevant Entities where it does not have a significant investment, and separately the applicable amount of direct and indirect holdings in Relevant Entities where it does have a significant investment. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] In addition, the CET1 deduction calculation includes other specified items such as current-year losses, IFRS-defined goodwill and other intangible assets, and deferred tax assets that rely on future profitability. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]

question: If an Authorised Person owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by a Relevant Entity, what facts make that ownership a “significant investment,” and how does that decision change which CET1 deduction bucket the holding goes into?
gold_answer: To place a holding into the correct CET1 deduction bucket, an Authorised Person must decide whether its holding in a Relevant Entity is a “significant investment,” because the CET1 rules distinguish between deductions for holdings where the Authorised Person has a significant investment and holdings where it does not. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] The holding is a significant investment if any one of these conditions applies: the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by the Relevant Entity; or the Authorised Person has Close Links with the entity and owns its CET1 Capital instruments; or the Authorised Person owns the entity’s CET1 Capital instruments and, while the entity is not consolidated under Chapter 8, it is included in the same IFRS accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for financial reporting. [#SRC:c9f19d0b-d036-4cfe-88ba-7e2528a70c11] If the holding meets one of those tests, the Authorised Person must treat it as a holding where it has a significant investment and deduct the applicable amount under the significant-investment category. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] If none of the tests are met, the holding falls into the non-significant-investment category and the applicable amount must be deducted under that separate category. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]

question: If an Authorised Person runs a Recognised Investment Exchange, Multilateral Trading Facility or an Organised Trading Facility for Accepted Spot Commodities, which MIR Chapter 5 rules do they have to follow in the listed Item situations, and how do the MIR words “Recognised Body” and “Financial Instrument” get read for Rule 22.7.4?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person in this position must comply with the MIR, Chapter 5 requirements that are specifically called out: Rules 5.1–5.3 and Rule 5.4.1, and this duty applies only in the circumstances identified in the enumerated Items (including Items 19, 20, 24(a) and (b), 27, 28, 32, 33, 35, 37, 38, 39, 41, 43, 45, 46, 47, 48, 49, 50, 52, 53, 54, 55, 57, 58, 59, 60, 61 and 62). [#TGT:3fec174f-e21d-4aa0-b244-0034deb32874] When interpreting MIR for the purposes of Rule 22.7.4 in this Accepted Spot Commodities context, you must also apply the required term substitutions: wherever MIR uses “Recognised Body” or “Recognised Bodies,” it is to be understood as “Authorised Person.” [#SRC:6f13bd3c-1af7-410b-8b34-a51c343db5a3] Similarly, wherever MIR uses “Financial Instrument” or “Financial Instruments,” it is to be understood as “Accepted Spot Commodity” or “Accepted Spot Commodities,” as appropriate. [#SRC:6f13bd3c-1af7-410b-8b34-a51c343db5a3] Putting these together, the Authorised Person applies the specified Chapter 5 rules in the listed Item situations, while reading those two MIR terms through the Rule 22.7.4 substitutions. [#TGT:3fec174f-e21d-4aa0-b244-0034deb32874] [#SRC:6f13bd3c-1af7-410b-8b34-a51c343db5a3]

question: Where a contravention is committed by one person, how does liability attach to another person who is Knowingly Concerned, and how do the consequences differ when the contravention is of FSMR or Rules versus a contravention of these Regulations?
gold_answer: If a contravention is committed by one person and another person is Knowingly Concerned in that contravention, both texts treat the involvement as a basis for liability for both individuals, but they describe the legal framing slightly differently depending on the instrument. [#SRC:a2dd84dd-1b01-465d-808a-b2f653dd4e93] [#TGT:5e4bc632-0693-4b1c-a3b9-ef28fb2a8441] For contraventions of FSMR or Rules, the SOURCE explains that when one person is Knowingly Concerned in another person’s contravention, section 220 of FSMR provides that both persons may be held liable for committing a contravention. [#SRC:a2dd84dd-1b01-465d-808a-b2f653dd4e93] For contraventions of these Regulations, the TARGET states that the person who is Knowingly Concerned, as well as the person who committed the underlying contravention, commits the contravention and is liable to be proceeded against and dealt with accordingly. [#TGT:5e4bc632-0693-4b1c-a3b9-ef28fb2a8441] In practical compliance terms, the shared trigger is the “Knowingly Concerned” involvement in another’s contravention, while the linkage across the two passages is that the SOURCE ties liability to section 220 of FSMR for FSMR/Rules contraventions, whereas the TARGET expressly describes exposure to being proceeded against for contraventions of these Regulations. [#SRC:a2dd84dd-1b01-465d-808a-b2f653dd4e93] [#TGT:5e4bc632-0693-4b1c-a3b9-ef28fb2a8441]

question: When an Authorised Person uses the FCSA to recognise eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure, how must it split the Exposure into collateralised and uncollateralised portions, and what CRW must it apply to the collateralised portion when the CRW applicable to the Collateral would otherwise be below 20%, including the specific exceptions that permit 0% or 10%?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person using the FCSA must treat eligible financial Collateral by separating the CR Exposure into two parts and then applying the appropriate CRW to each part, with a floor on the collateralised portion unless an exception applies. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] The collateralised portion must be set equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and the uncollateralised portion must be the CR Exposure amount reduced by that latest fair value. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] For Credit RWA calculation purposes, the collateralised portion generally takes the CRW applicable to the Collateral as if the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to it, while the uncollateralised portion takes the CRW applicable to the obligor. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] However, if the CRW that would be used for the collateralised portion (i.e., the CRW applicable to the Collateral) is below 20%, the Authorised Person must apply 20% to the collateralised portion unless one of the specified cases applies. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438] The exceptions include qualifying SFTs (0% if the Counterparty is a core market participant; 10% if not), certain daily-marked OTC Derivatives with no currency mismatch (0% if collateralised by cash; 10% if collateralised by specified 0%-risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures), and certain no-currency-mismatch transactions where the Collateral is specified cash on Deposit or specified 0%-risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures and the latest fair value used for the collateralised portion has been discounted by 20%. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438]

question: If an Authorised Person is using the FCSA and the Collateral’s risk weight would come out below 20%, what do they do with the Exposure split (collateralised vs uncollateralised) and when can they use 0% or 10% instead of 20% for the collateralised part?
gold_answer: Under the FCSA approach, the Authorised Person must first split the CR Exposure into a collateralised portion and an uncollateralised portion, and then apply risk weights to each portion based on what each portion represents. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] The collateralised portion is measured as the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and the uncollateralised portion is the CR Exposure amount minus that latest fair value. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] For Credit RWA purposes, the collateralised portion uses the CRW that applies to the Collateral as if it were a direct Exposure to that Collateral, while the uncollateralised portion uses the CRW that applies to the obligor. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] If the CRW for the collateralised portion (based on the Collateral) would be less than 20%, the default outcome is that the Authorised Person must apply a 20% CRW to the collateralised portion. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438] The Authorised Person may instead apply 0% or 10% only in the listed cases, including qualifying SFTs depending on whether the Counterparty is a core market participant, and certain daily mark-to-market OTC Derivative transactions with no currency mismatch depending on whether the Collateral is cash or specified 0%-risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438] A further 0% option exists for certain no-currency-mismatch transactions where the Collateral is specified cash on Deposit or specified 0%-risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures and the latest fair value used in the collateralised portion has been discounted by 20%. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity publishes forecast financial information derived from a Production Target and, in the same disclosure package, also discloses an estimate of Ore Reserves, what specific categories of assumptions and supporting information must be included for (i) the forecast financial information and (ii) the Ore Reserves estimate, including how commercially sensitive material economic assumptions are to be handled?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must ensure the disclosure covers two distinct but complementary information sets: the assumption framework supporting the forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, and the key technical context required when an Ore Reserves estimate is disclosed. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129] For the forecast financial information, the disclosure must include all material economic assumptions used, plus all other material assumptions applied. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must state that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions (rather than omitting the topic entirely). [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] The disclosure must also identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, and include the information required to be contained in that Production Target disclosure. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Separately, when disclosing an estimate of Ore Reserves, the disclosure must also include key information on mining (recovery/dilution) factors or assumptions, metallurgical factors or assumptions, cut-off parameters, study status, and the relative accuracy/confidence. [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129]

question: When calculating the Exposure value for on-balance sheet SFTs, how should an Authorised Person reflect the netting approach described for legally valid bilateral netting that substitutes a single payable/receivable amount, and what calculation framework must be used?
gold_answer: For on-balance sheet SFTs, the Exposure value must be calculated using the IFRS-based approach specified for SFTs, and it must incorporate the applicable netting requirements for those SFTs. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] Where the Authorised Person applies a legally valid form of bilateral netting that produces legal substitution—i.e., replacing prior gross obligations with one single payable/receivable amount—this netting concept is the type of netting that may be used to net transactions and should be reflected in how the SFT exposure is determined under the referenced netting requirements. [#TGT:af6814ee-9972-4eb9-996b-eb4446ec5113] In practical terms, the calculation is anchored in IFRS for the on-balance sheet measurement of the SFT exposure, while the netting treatment is constrained to bilateral netting arrangements that are legally valid and achieve legal substitution into a single net amount. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:af6814ee-9972-4eb9-996b-eb4446ec5113] This linkage matters because the SFT exposure rule requires both the IFRS calculation basis and compliance with the netting requirements, and the netting-set concept clarifies the kind of bilateral netting that can be used to arrive at a single net payable/receivable amount rather than gross obligations. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:af6814ee-9972-4eb9-996b-eb4446ec5113]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information derived from a Production Target for an operating mine, in what circumstances is it not required to comply with Rule 11.9.2, and what specific content must still be included in the disclosure under Rule 11.9.1 (including how to handle commercially sensitive material economic assumptions)?
