gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is not required to comply with Rule 11.9.2 for forecast financial information derived from a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) where that forecast financial information is wholly based on (i) Ore Reserves, (ii) a combination of Ore Reserves and Measured Mineral Resources, or (iii) a combination of Ore Reserves with Measured Mineral Resources and/or Indicated Mineral Resources, provided the Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability. [#SRC:bf5c6652-b4c7-4b61-8732-68aed56e52a7] Even in that scenario, if the Mining Reporting Entity is making a disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1, the disclosure must include the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, covering all material economic assumptions employed and all other material assumptions utilised. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it must state that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] The Rule 11.9.1 disclosure must also identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including all information required by Rule 11.8.3. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s forecast financial information comes from a Production Target for an operating mine, when can it skip complying with Rule 11.9.2, and what does it still have to put in its Rule 11.9.1 disclosure (especially if the economic assumptions are commercially sensitive)?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity can avoid having to comply with Rule 11.9.2 for forecast financial information derived from a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) when the forecast is wholly based on Ore Reserves, or on Ore Reserves combined with Measured Mineral Resources, or on Ore Reserves combined with Measured Mineral Resources and/or Indicated Mineral Resources as long as the Indicated Mineral Resources are not what determines whether the project is viable. [#SRC:bf5c6652-b4c7-4b61-8732-68aed56e52a7] However, where the Mining Reporting Entity is making a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1, it still must include details about the assumptions used to work out the forecast financial information, including all material economic assumptions and all other material assumptions. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If it believes the material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it must say they are commercially sensitive and describe the methodology it used to determine those assumptions. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] It must also include the Production Target the forecast is based on, and that Production Target must be presented with all the information required by Rule 11.8.3. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]

question: Where a FinTech Participant cannot meet the applicable criteria, when must it stop carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab, and how does the Regulator’s ability to vary or cancel a Financial Services Permission affect that deadline under the framework addressing variation and cancellation on the Regulator’s initiative?
gold_answer: If a FinTech Participant is unable to satisfy the applicable criteria, it must stop carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] The default deadline for ceasing that Regulated Activity is the point when its RegLab FSP expires, reflecting the stated two-year validity period for that permission. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] However, that deadline is not fixed solely by expiry: it can be brought forward (or otherwise altered) if the Regulator varies or cancels the FSP, because the cessation deadline is also defined as “at such time as the Regulator varies or cancels the FSP” in accordance with the referenced mechanism. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] In applying this, the relevant framework is the regime concerning “Variation and cancellation of a Financial Services Permission,” specifically where variation or cancellation occurs on the initiative of the Regulator. [#TGT:445d41e7-27aa-41c1-84e4-194553261f8a] Accordingly, compliance planning should treat expiry as the baseline stop date, but also monitor for any Regulator-initiated variation or cancellation that would trigger an earlier (or otherwise revised) cessation point. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] [#TGT:445d41e7-27aa-41c1-84e4-194553261f8a]

question: For Derivative transactions (including written credit protection) that are on-balance sheet items, how should the firm determine the exposure measure, and how does that interact with the requirement to calculate exposure at default (EAD) for Derivative transactions under the Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR) unless the Authorised Person has Regulator permission to use an internal model?
gold_answer: For on-balance sheet Derivatives (including written credit protection), the firm should build the exposure measure by combining two components: (1) the on-balance sheet value determined under IFRS and (2) an add-on for potential future exposure calculated under Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] In parallel, the exposure at default (EAD) for Derivative transactions (whether OTC or exchange-traded) must be calculated in accordance with the SA-CCR section, and this SA-CCR requirement also applies to long settlement transactions. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] The linkage is that, when the Derivative is an on-balance sheet item, the exposure value construction (IFRS on-balance sheet value plus the specified potential future exposure add-on) provides the concrete inputs and method elements the firm uses to operationalize its Derivative exposure calculation, while the SA-CCR section establishes that the firm must calculate EAD under that section for Derivative transactions unless it has been granted permission by the Regulator to use an internal model. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] If the Authorised Person has Regulator permission to use an internal model, the SA-CCR calculation mandate does not apply in the same way for those transactions. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff]

question: When an Authorised Person is calculating RWA for all its securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures), how must it treat Early Amortisation Exposures within that overall calculation, including (i) the formula and risk-weight basis used for Early Amortisation Exposures and (ii) how those results are combined with the RWA for other SE Exposures?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must compute RWA for its SE Exposures by calculating RWA for each SE Exposure (other than those required to be deducted from any component of Capital Resources) and then combining those amounts with the separately calculated RWA for its Early Amortisation Exposures. [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] For each SE Exposure that is not deducted from Capital Resources, it must first determine the Exposure value under the Section 4.9 exposure measurement methodology while recognising applicable CRM, assign a Credit Quality Grade under Section 4.11, and then apply the formula RWA(SE) = SE × CRW, where CRW is the risk weight determined from that Credit Quality Grade. [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] In parallel, for each Early Amortisation Exposure it must calculate the Exposure value (EAE) under Section 4.9 while recognising applicable CRM and then compute RWA(EAE) = EAE × CRW, where CRW is the risk weight for the underlying Exposure type as if the Exposure had not been securitised. [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e] Finally, it must add together (i) the RWA(SE) amounts across all relevant SE Exposures and (ii) the aggregated RWA(EAE) amounts across all Early Amortisation Exposures to arrive at the combined RWA total for these securitisation-related positions. [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e]

question: If an Authorised Person has both SE Exposures and Early Amortisation Exposures, what steps does it follow to work out the risk-weighted amounts for each type, and how are the two sets of results added together?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must calculate risk-weighted Exposure amounts separately for SE Exposures and for Early Amortisation Exposures, and then add the totals together as part of the overall securitisation-related RWA calculation. [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] For SE Exposures, it must measure each Exposure value using the Section 4.9 methodology while recognising any applicable CRM, allocate a Credit Quality Grade under Section 4.11, and then compute RWA(SE) = SE × CRW, where CRW is the risk weight that corresponds to that Credit Quality Grade. [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] For Early Amortisation Exposures, it must measure each Exposure value (EAE) using the same Section 4.9 methodology and CRM recognition, and then compute RWA(EAE) = EAE × CRW. [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e] The key difference is that, for Early Amortisation Exposures, CRW is taken from the underlying Exposure type as though the Exposure had not been securitised, rather than being derived from a Credit Quality Grade. [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e] After calculating each set, it must sum the RWA(EAE) amounts across all Early Amortisation Exposures and add that sum to the RWA(SE) amounts calculated for its SE Exposures (excluding any SE Exposures required to be deducted from Capital Resources). [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e]

question: Where a Listed Entity has issued, or agreed to issue, Securities without prior approval, under what conditions is that issue treated as approved for Rule 9.7.1 purposes, and how does that treatment affect whether those Securities are excluded from “Relevant Issues” when applying the 20% formula restriction on new Issues of Equity Securities?
gold_answer: An unapproved issue (or agreement to issue) Securities can be treated as if it had approval for Rule 9.7.1, but only if three conditions are met: it stayed within the Rule 9.7.1 limit, the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities later approve it, and the Securities are then issued within three months after that approval date. [#SRC:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6] Once that subsequent approval treatment applies, the issue is treated as having approval “for the purposes of Rule 9.7.1,” which matters when calculating the restriction on new issues because “Relevant Issues” excludes Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months if they were made with approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 (or Rule 9.7.5). [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] In practical terms, if the Securities are Equity Securities and the subsequent-approval conditions are satisfied, the Listed Entity can treat them as approved under Rule 9.7.1 for the exclusion test in the “Relevant Issues” definition, rather than counting them toward the prior-12-month total that reduces the maximum number available under the 20% * Base Amount formula. [#SRC:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6] [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]

question: When an Authorised Person is determining the Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by applying jurisdictional buffer rates to its private sector credit exposures, how should it identify which exposures qualify as “private sector credit exposures,” and what quantitative base must those rates be applied to?
gold_answer: To calculate the Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital, an Authorised Person must first ensure it is using the correct population of “private sector credit exposures” for determining which jurisdictions’ countercyclical buffer rates apply, and then apply the resulting weighted average rate to the required quantitative base. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] “Private sector credit exposures” are specifically those exposures for which Credit RWAs must be calculated under Chapter 4, but excluding exposures that fall within the listed asset classes (Central government and central bank, Public sector enterprises, Multilateral development bank (MDB), International organisation, and Bank). [#TGT:5d947e78-d9be-42d5-aad3-95b3528ea88c] Once the Authorised Person has identified the relevant private sector credit exposures and the jurisdictions where those exposures are located (so that the applicable jurisdictional buffer rates can be weighted and averaged), the buffer amount must be computed as the Total Risk Exposure Amount (as calculated under Rule 3.5.7) multiplied by that weighted average of the applicable countercyclical buffer rates (as calculated under Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8). [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]

question: For an Authorised Person measuring E for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT that is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement, how is E determined for (i) lending or selling Securities with a commitment to repurchase and (ii) lending or paying cash with a commitment to resell, and in what circumstances may the Authorised Person recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral when the exposure is determined under Rule 4.9.15?
gold_answer: E must be measured using the specified transaction-type amounts when the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arises from an SFT that is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement, and eligible financial Collateral may only be recognised where the SFT exposure is determined under Rule 4.9.15 and the collateral is eligible financial Collateral taken for that SFT. [#TGT:9578677d-803d-4f27-b8f6-2e4bdf56805e] [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] Where the Authorised Person has lent Securities to a Counterparty or sold Securities to a Counterparty with a commitment to repurchase those Securities at a specified price on a specified future date, E is the latest fair value of the Securities lent or sold. [#TGT:9578677d-803d-4f27-b8f6-2e4bdf56805e] Where the Authorised Person has lent cash to a Counterparty through borrowing Securities from the Counterparty, or has paid cash to purchase Securities from a Counterparty with a commitment to resell those Securities at a specified price on a specified future date, E is the amount of cash lent or paid. [#TGT:9578677d-803d-4f27-b8f6-2e4bdf56805e] Separately, if the Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15, the Authorised Person may recognise the effect of that collateral, but only in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]

question: If an Authorised Person has an SFT pre settlement Counterparty Exposure that is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement, what number do they use for E in the two SFT cases listed, and when can they take eligible financial Collateral into account if the exposure is determined under Rule 4.9.15?
gold_answer: For an SFT pre settlement Counterparty Exposure that is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement, the Authorised Person must calculate E using the rule that matches the SFT type, and eligible financial Collateral can only be reflected when the exposure is determined under Rule 4.9.15 and the collateral is eligible financial Collateral taken for that SFT. [#TGT:9578677d-803d-4f27-b8f6-2e4bdf56805e] [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] Specifically, if the Authorised Person lends Securities to a Counterparty or sells Securities to a Counterparty and agrees to buy back those Securities later at a set price and date, E is the latest fair value of the Securities that were lent or sold. [#TGT:9578677d-803d-4f27-b8f6-2e4bdf56805e] If instead the Authorised Person lends cash (by borrowing Securities from the Counterparty) or pays cash to buy Securities and agrees to sell those Securities back later at a set price and date, E is the amount of cash lent or paid. [#TGT:9578677d-803d-4f27-b8f6-2e4bdf56805e] When the Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and the exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15, the effect of that collateral may be recognised, but only by applying Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]

question: Where a Payment Service Provider offers a Single Payment Service Contract that is also intended to sit within a Framework Contract, what pre-contract information must be provided to the Payment Service User before they are bound, and how should that be aligned with the Framework Contract’s required disclosures on execution timing, identifiers, and charges (including exchange-rate details where relevant)?
gold_answer: The Payment Service Provider must ensure the Payment Service User receives specified pre-contract information for the Single Payment Service Contract before the Payment Service User becomes bound, and that this pre-contract package is consistent with the corresponding Framework Contract disclosures on the same topics. [#SRC:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55] Before the Payment Service User is bound, the Payment Service Provider must provide or make available (for example via a draft Single Payment Service Contract or draft Payment Order) the identifier or other information the Payment Service User must supply for proper initiation/execution, the maximum execution time, the charges (and breakdown where applicable), and—where applicable—the actual or Reference Exchange Rate to be applied. [#SRC:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55] In parallel, the Framework Contract must include, among other items, the identifier information for initiating/executing Payment Orders, the maximum execution time for the Payment Services, and detailed charges payable (including charges connected to information being provided/made available and a breakdown where applicable). [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] Where exchange rates are relevant, the Framework Contract must also include the exchange rates to be applied or, if Reference Exchange Rates are used, the method for calculating the relevant date for determining them. [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]

question: If a Payment Service Provider is preparing a Framework Contract and also intends to satisfy the Single Payment Service Contract pre-binding disclosure by supplying a draft Payment Order, which specific information items must be covered in the pre-binding disclosure and which additional Framework Contract items must still be included (particularly around consent procedure and cut-off/time-of-receipt concepts)?
gold_answer: Using a draft Payment Order as the delivery method does not change the minimum content that must be provided before the Payment Service User is bound by the Single Payment Service Contract, and it does not remove the need for the Framework Contract to contain its broader set of mandatory terms. [#SRC:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55] For the Single Payment Service Contract, the Payment Service Provider must provide or make available, before the Payment Service User is bound, the information/unique identifier the Payment Service User must provide for proper initiation or execution, the maximum execution time, the charges payable (with a breakdown where applicable), and—where applicable—the actual or Reference Exchange Rate to be applied. [#SRC:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55] Separately, the Framework Contract must include additional operational and procedural information beyond those pre-binding items, including the form and procedure for giving consent to initiation/execution and for withdrawing consent, as well as the time of receipt of a Payment Order and any cut-off time for processing established by the Payment Service Provider. [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] The Framework Contract must also include the required charges and exchange-rate disclosures (including, where relevant, the method for determining the relevant date for Reference Exchange Rates). [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]

question: If an Authorised Person runs an MTF or OTF and has to follow certain MIR rules as if it were a Recognised Body or Recognised Investment Exchange, what word should it use when those MIR/COBS materials talk about “Investments” or “Financial Instruments” for Rule 17.7.2 purposes?
gold_answer: For an Authorised Person that is an MTF Operator or OTF Operator, the MIR requirements listed for Recognised Bodies or Recognised Investment Exchanges must be applied by treating the operator as the entity the MIR rules are referring to (i.e., reading those entity references as the MTF Operator or OTF Operator). [#TGT:180edda8-db12-4969-97d5-182435bdf094] Separately, for the purposes of Rule 17.7.2, COBS Chapter 8 contains a specific instruction on how to read certain instrument terms, and that instruction also covers instances where MIR text appears because MIR is incorporated into COBS Chapter 8 (including via COBS Rule 8.2.1). [#SRC:a3736367-db02-465d-809f-1bc6cfd7bbcd] Under that reading rule, whenever the relevant COBS Chapter 8 material uses “Investment” or “Investments,” you must treat it as meaning “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets,” as applicable. [#SRC:a3736367-db02-465d-809f-1bc6cfd7bbcd] Likewise, whenever it uses “Financial Instrument” or “Financial Instruments” (including where those terms appear in MIR provisions that are pulled into COBS Chapter 8), you must treat those terms as “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets,” as applicable. [#SRC:a3736367-db02-465d-809f-1bc6cfd7bbcd] Putting the two together: you apply the MIR rulebook obligations in the operator’s capacity, and you interpret the covered instrument labels in the incorporated COBS Chapter 8 context as referring to Virtual Assets. [#TGT:180edda8-db12-4969-97d5-182435bdf094] [#SRC:a3736367-db02-465d-809f-1bc6cfd7bbcd]

question: If an Authorised Person can withdraw from an Underwriting commitment using an irrevocable right that lasts for a set period, when does the commitment start, and how does that interact with the usual rule about signing the agreement or setting the price and allocation for the issue of Securities?
gold_answer: When the Authorised Person has an irrevocable right (at its discretion) to withdraw from an Underwriting commitment and that right can be used only within a specified period, the commitment is treated as starting when the withdrawal right period ends (i.e., when the right expires). [#TGT:d9495a44-ecf5-4db3-bd33-e8da8d5b4a76] Outside that specific situation (or after the right has expired), the Authorised Person must treat the initial commitment to underwrite an issue of Securities—subject to any right set out in Rule 5.10.6—as beginning from whichever happens first: signing an underwriting agreement with the Issuer of Securities, or the point when the price and allocation of the issue are set. [#SRC:5e3c35e9-6a09-4cca-aa79-0467e4867446] So the practical sequence is: check whether the underwriting arrangement includes the described irrevocable withdrawal right and note its expiry date; if it does, use that expiry as the start of the commitment. [#TGT:d9495a44-ecf5-4db3-bd33-e8da8d5b4a76] If it does not (or once it has expired), determine the start by comparing the signing time against the time price and allocation are set, and choose the earlier of those two. [#SRC:5e3c35e9-6a09-4cca-aa79-0467e4867446]

question: When a Listed Entity proposes an issue of Securities that is intended to be made with the approval of the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.5.3 (Related Party Transaction), what approval mechanics and voting restrictions must be satisfied, and how do those requirements change if there is a material change to the terms after approval but before completion?
gold_answer: For an issue of Securities that is made with the approval of the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.5.3 (Related Party Transaction), the Listed Entity must structure the process as a Shareholder approval for the proposed Related Party Transaction and obtain prior approval by a majority of the Shareholders before entering into the transaction when the 5% net-assets threshold is met or exceeded. [#SRC:0e803fa7-08d6-46fa-802d-ed7fe0c0cfd4] [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de] In addition, the Related Party must not vote on that Shareholder resolution and must take all reasonable steps to ensure any Related Party Associates also do not vote. [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de] If, after obtaining Shareholder approval under Rule 9.5.3(1) but before completion of the Related Party Transaction, there is a material change to the terms of the proposed transaction, the Listed Entity must separately comply again with the same Shareholder-approval requirement for that Related Party Transaction (i.e., re-seek approval under Rule 9.5.3(1)). [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de] These mechanics apply in the specific context where the securities issuance is being carried out on the basis of approval by holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.5.3. [#SRC:0e803fa7-08d6-46fa-802d-ed7fe0c0cfd4]

question: If a Listed Entity plans an issue of Securities and wants to rely on approval from holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.5.3, what does it have to do when the Related Party Transaction is below the 5% net-assets threshold, and what extra step applies if a series of unapproved transactions with the same Related Party reaches 5% within 12 months?
gold_answer: Where the issue of Securities is being made using approval from holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.5.3 (Related Party Transaction), the Listed Entity must apply the Related Party Transaction procedures that distinguish between transactions below and at/above the 5% net-assets threshold. [#SRC:0e803fa7-08d6-46fa-802d-ed7fe0c0cfd4] [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de] If the value of the proposed Related Party Transaction is less than 5% of the value of the net assets of the Listed Entity (as stated in its most recent financial reports), the Reporting Entity must, as soon as possible after entering the transaction, notify the Regulator of the relevant terms and explain the basis on which those terms are considered fair and reasonable, supported by written confirmation from an independent third party. [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de] It must also disclose the Related Party Transaction in accordance with Rule 7.7.1. [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de] Separately, if there is a series of Related Party Transactions with the same Related Party that have not received Shareholder approval and their cumulative value reaches the 5% threshold in any 12 month period, the Listed Entity must not enter into the last transaction in that series unless it is put to Shareholder approval and receives approval by a majority of the Shareholders in voting. [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de] This ties back to the securities issuance being undertaken in the Rule 9.5.3 approval context. [#SRC:0e803fa7-08d6-46fa-802d-ed7fe0c0cfd4]

question: If an Authorised Person uses the FCCA and takes eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is not under a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, what number should they use instead of E when working out the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount, and how do they calculate it (including what haircuts and values go into the formula)?
gold_answer: They must use E* instead of E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for the CR Exposure, because the transaction is an SFT with eligible financial Collateral, the FCCA is used, and there is no qualifying bilateral Netting agreement. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de] E* is the exposure value after risk mitigation and must be calculated using the FCCA haircut method formula for collateralised transactions that are not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement (and, here, the transaction is not described as an OTC Derivative transaction or a long settlement transaction). [#TGT:bfe1d138-bbe5-4cfd-b804-a89cccbf6949] The calculation is: E* = max{0, [E(1+HE) − C(1−HC−HFX)]}. [#TGT:bfe1d138-bbe5-4cfd-b804-a89cccbf6949] In that formula, E is the fair value of the Exposure (calculated under the referenced section), C is the fair value of the eligible financial Collateral received, HE is the haircut for the Exposure, HC is the haircut for the Collateral (or a weighted sum if the Collateral is a basket of assets), and HFX is the haircut for any currency mismatch between the Collateral and the Exposure. [#TGT:bfe1d138-bbe5-4cfd-b804-a89cccbf6949] Once E* is computed, it is substituted for E in the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount calculation for that CR Exposure. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de]

question: For an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, how should the required minimum systems and controls for Virtual Asset wallets and key management be integrated into the broader technology governance expectations on system maintenance/testing and third-party interfaces, so that both sets of requirements are met?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets must implement documented systems and controls for Virtual Asset wallets and for private/public keys, and those controls should be embedded within a wider technology governance framework that also addresses system upkeep/testing and third-party service interfaces. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] [#SRC:a5118140-500d-49f4-85a9-6a18ef85d7f2] Practically, this means the wallet and key procedures are not standalone documents; they should be maintained and evolved through disciplined system development practices (such as controlled updates, issue resolution, and regular internal and third-party testing) so the controls remain effective as the architecture changes. [#SRC:a5118140-500d-49f4-85a9-6a18ef85d7f2] At a minimum, the wallet procedures should cover lifecycle activities (setup/configuration/deployment/deletion/backup and recovery), access privilege and user management, rule/limit determination with review and updates, and audit/oversight, while key procedures should address generation, exchange, storage, backup, destruction, access management, public key sharing, and re-use where applicable. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] Where any wallet or key functionality relies on external providers (e.g., custody tooling, cloud services, or data/service recipients), the Authorised Person should also maintain procedures governing the creation and management of services, interfaces, and channels provided by or to third parties to ensure those dependencies are controlled. [#SRC:a5118140-500d-49f4-85a9-6a18ef85d7f2]

question: When designing controls to mitigate misuse of Virtual Assets by determining the origin of incoming transactions and the destination of outgoing transactions, what additional technology governance elements must an Authorised Person address regarding security of data transmission/storage and business continuity planning for outages?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must implement systems and controls that explain how the origin of Virtual Assets is determined for incoming transactions and how the destination is determined for outgoing transactions, and those controls must be supported by technology governance measures that protect data and maintain service resilience. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] [#SRC:a5118140-500d-49f4-85a9-6a18ef85d7f2] In practice, the transaction-origin/destination controls should be designed alongside security measures and procedures for the safe storage and transmission of data, because determining origin/destination depends on handling transaction and related information in a way that is protected in transit and at rest. [#SRC:a5118140-500d-49f4-85a9-6a18ef85d7f2] The Authorised Person must also have a security plan describing arrangements for privacy of sensitive data, networks and systems, cloud-based services, physical facilities, and documents/document storage, which provides a structured baseline for safeguarding the information used in these determinations. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] Additionally, the technology governance expectations include business continuity and Client engagement planning for both planned and unplanned system outages; this is relevant because origin/destination determinations must remain operationally manageable even when systems are disrupted. [#SRC:a5118140-500d-49f4-85a9-6a18ef85d7f2] Taken together, the misuse-mitigation controls should be implemented with secure data handling and outage planning so the control objective is maintained under normal and disrupted conditions. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] [#SRC:a5118140-500d-49f4-85a9-6a18ef85d7f2]

question: For an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, how should the firm align the contents of its Resolution Pack with its broader obligation to maintain records for at least six years, specifically for Client classification and Client agreements?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business should treat the Resolution Pack as a defined subset of its wider recordkeeping population and ensure that the Client classification and Client agreement materials that must appear in the Resolution Pack are also maintained within the firm’s general records for at least six years. [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2] In practice, this means the Resolution Pack must include the records tied to Client classification and Client agreements identified for inclusion, and those same categories must be retained as part of the firm’s sufficient records maintained for the minimum six-year period. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2] Specifically, the Resolution Pack must contain the records of Client classification and Client agreements referenced for Investment Business, and the firm’s general recordkeeping must include documents regarding Client classification under Chapter 2 and a record of each Client Agreement (including later amendments agreed with the Client). [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2] Operationally, the firm should ensure its filing and retention approach allows the Resolution Pack copies (or pointers to them) to be preserved for the full six years as part of the sufficient records maintained for each activity and function. [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2]

question: When compiling the Resolution Pack for an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, which Client Money/Client Investments record types must be included, and how does the six-year minimum retention requirement shape how those records are maintained?
gold_answer: The Resolution Pack for an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must include specific Client Money and Client Investments record types, and those records should be maintained within the firm’s overall recordkeeping framework for at least six years. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2] For Resolution Pack content, the required items include master lists of all Client Accounts relating to Client Money and Client investments, records and the Client’s written permission regarding use of Client Investments, assessments of appropriateness of Third-Party Agent and acknowledgements by the Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Money and separately in respect of Client Investments, and the most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] The retention obligation means the Authorised Person must maintain sufficient records for a minimum of six years in relation to each activity and function, and the Resolution Pack materials should be kept in a way that satisfies that minimum period (even though the Resolution Pack list itself is framed as inclusion requirements). [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2] Where applicable, the firm’s six-year records set also includes items such as records of Financial Instruments provided to or Regulated Activities carried out for the benefit of a Client and related advice or recommendations, which can help contextualise and support the Client Money/Client Investments records maintained and packaged. [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2]

question: When a party that is managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 seeks the Regulator’s consent to release that holding lock so holders of Restricted Securities can accept an offer (or transfer/cancel Securities) under a Takeover, what specific preconditions must be satisfied for the Regulator to provide consent, including the acceptance threshold and any written agreement to immediately re-impose the holding lock if the Takeover does not complete or Securities are not acquired?
gold_answer: The Regulator may consent to the release of a holding lock managed under Rule 9.6.9 to allow holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer, or to transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover. [#TGT:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67] However, the Regulator will not provide that consent unless the applicable conditions for the relevant transaction structure are met. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] Where there is an offer for Securities, the offer must cover all Ordinary Securities, or if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, it must cover all Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] In addition, holders of at least half of the Securities (to which the offer relates) that are not Restricted Securities must have accepted the offer. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder must agree in writing that the holding lock imposed under Rule 9.6.9 is immediately re-imposed for each Security not bought by the offeror under the offer. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If the Takeover is conducted by way of a scheme, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity in which the Restricted Securities are held must agree in writing that the holding lock imposed under Rule 9.6.9 is immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd]

question: If someone managing a holding lock under Rule 9.6.9 wants the Regulator to let Restricted Securities holders take part in a Takeover (by accepting an offer or transferring/cancelling Securities), what does the offer have to cover, what level of acceptance is needed from non-Restricted Securities holders, and when do the parties have to agree in writing to put the holding lock back on?
gold_answer: A party managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 can ask the Regulator to allow the holding lock to be released so holders of Restricted Securities can accept an offer, or transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover. [#TGT:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67] The Regulator will only provide consent if the applicable conditions are met for the way the Takeover is being done. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If the Takeover involves an offer for Securities, the offer must be for all of the Ordinary Securities, or (if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities) for all Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] Also, at least half of the holders of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities (and that the offer relates to) must have accepted the offer. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder must agree in writing that the holding lock imposed under Rule 9.6.9 is immediately re-imposed for each Security the offeror does not buy. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If the Takeover is done by a scheme, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity must agree in writing to immediately re-impose the holding lock if the Takeover does not take effect. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd]

question: Where a person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator is liable to pay compensation for loss suffered by an acquirer of Securities due to an untrue or misleading statement, or a missing material matter required to be included, what specific showings can that person rely on to avoid incurring civil liability, including any steps that must be taken before the Securities are acquired in reliance on the Prospectus?
gold_answer: A person who is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus can face an obligation to pay compensation to someone who acquired the relevant Securities and suffered loss or damage because the Prospectus contained an untrue or misleading statement or omitted a material matter that was required to be included. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] However, that person does not incur civil liability if they can establish one of the specified defenses tied to the accuracy of the Prospectus, the reasonableness of their diligence, or timely corrective action. [#SRC:4ce33793-6bb5-4bc3-a65f-675a4ac19554] To avoid civil liability in this compensation context, the person must be able to show at least one of the following: (i) the relevant statement was true (and not false, misleading, or deceptive) or that the matter whose omission caused the loss was properly omitted; (ii) they made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances and believed there was no false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission in the Prospectus; or (iii) before any person acquired the Securities in reliance on the Prospectus, they took all steps that were reasonable for them to take to ensure a correction was promptly made and brought to the attention of persons likely to acquire the Securities. [#SRC:4ce33793-6bb5-4bc3-a65f-675a4ac19554]

question: If someone is listed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, and an investor buys the Securities and loses money because the Prospectus had an untrue or misleading statement or left out a required material matter, what can that liable person prove or do to avoid civil liability—especially what must happen before the investor acquires the Securities relying on the Prospectus?
gold_answer: If a person is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, they can be required to pay compensation to a person who acquired the Securities covered by that Prospectus and suffered loss or damage because of an untrue or misleading statement or because a required material matter was omitted. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] Even in that setting, the person can avoid incurring civil liability if they can demonstrate one of the defenses that focus on truthfulness, reasonable investigation, or prompt correction before acquisition. [#SRC:4ce33793-6bb5-4bc3-a65f-675a4ac19554] In practice, the liable person must be able to show at least one of these: the statement was actually true (and not false, misleading, or deceptive), or the omitted matter that caused the loss was properly left out; they made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances and believed the Prospectus contained no false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission; or, crucially, before the Securities were acquired by anyone relying on the Prospectus, they took all steps that were reasonable for them to take to get a correction made promptly and to bring that correction to the attention of people likely to acquire the Securities. [#SRC:4ce33793-6bb5-4bc3-a65f-675a4ac19554]

question: When performing a business risk assessment that specifically covers the carrying on of NFTF business and the use of eKYC Systems, what must a Relevant Person do to identify and assess the full scope of money laundering-related risks and vulnerabilities, and how should it incorporate mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, or other relevant bodies into day-to-day operations?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person conducting a business risk assessment that addresses NFTF business and the use of eKYC Systems must both (i) identify and assess the money laundering risks its business faces and (ii) ensure the assessment is operationalised through mitigation in day-to-day activities, while considering relevant external mitigation measures. [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851] The assessment should explicitly cover risks associated with carrying on NFTF business, with particular attention to the use of eKYC Systems. [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2] In identifying and assessing risk, it must take appropriate steps that reflect the nature, size and complexity of its activities, and treat money laundering risk as including terrorist financing, proliferation financing, the financing of unlawful organisations, and sanctions non-compliance (including non-compliance with Targeted Financial Sanctions). [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851] It must also consider, to the extent relevant, vulnerabilities tied to customer types, geographies, products and services, distribution channels and partners, transaction complexity/volume, new products and practices, and the use of new or developing technologies—linking this technology lens to eKYC Systems used in NFTF business. [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851] The assessment should consider incorporating any relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and other relevant bodies, and the Relevant Person must take appropriate measures so identified risks are mitigated in operations, including for new products, new customers, and changes to its business profile. [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2] [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]

question: If a Relevant Person is reviewing risks for NFTF business and especially the use of eKYC Systems, what kinds of risks and weak spots must it look at, and how should it use mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, or other relevant bodies so the results affect daily work (like new products or new customers)?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the Relevant Person must run a risk assessment that is broad enough to cover money laundering risk (including related categories) and detailed enough to address NFTF business and the use of eKYC Systems, then make sure the findings drive practical mitigation in daily operations. [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851] The business risk assessment should include evaluating risks linked to carrying on NFTF business, with particular focus on eKYC Systems. [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2] When identifying and assessing risks, it must take steps that consider the nature, size and complexity of its activities, and it must treat money laundering risks as also covering terrorist financing, proliferation financing, the financing of unlawful organisations, and sanctions non-compliance (including Targeted Financial Sanctions). [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851] It must also look (as relevant) at vulnerabilities involving customers, countries/geographic areas, products/services/activity profiles, distribution channels and business partners, transaction complexity and volume, new products and practices, and the use of new or developing technologies—connecting that technology review to eKYC Systems used in NFTF business. [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851] The assessment should consider incorporating mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and other relevant bodies, and the Relevant Person must ensure identified risks are taken into account and mitigated in day-to-day operations, including when developing new products, taking on new customers, and responding to changes in its business profile. [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2] [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, how can it avoid having to comply with Rule 11.2.1(1), and what specific disclosure content must it still ensure is included (including the required prominent statement and the Competent Person-related elements)?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity that discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation may treat Rule 11.2.1(1) as not applicable only if it instead complies with the specified alternative rules (Rule 11.7.2, Rule 11.7.3, Rule 11.7.4, and Rule 11.7.6). [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] Even when relying on that carve-out, the entity must still ensure the disclosure contains the required Non-Equivalent Estimates content, including a prominent nearby statement that the estimates are Non-Equivalent Estimates not made under a Mining Reporting Standard, that a Competent Person has not done enough work to classify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard, and that it is uncertain whether further evaluation/exploration will ever allow such disclosure under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] The disclosure must also include the sources and dates of the estimates; explain whether any Mineralisation categories used differ from (or match) those in a Mining Reporting Standard; address relevance and reliability; summarise the work and key assumptions/parameters/methods used; provide any newer relevant estimates/data with sources and dates; and describe what work is needed to verify the estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, including proposed timing and funding source. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] Finally, it must state the classification/reporting standard used and include a statement by a named Competent Person(s) attesting that the information provided for items (3) to (9) accurately reflects available data and studies. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity shares material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, when does it not have to follow Rule 11.2.1(1), and what information still has to be put into the disclosure (especially what must be said about the Mining Reporting Standard and the Competent Person)?
gold_answer: Rule 11.2.1(1) does not need to be followed for a Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure of material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation only where the Mining Reporting Entity instead complies with Rule 11.7.2, Rule 11.7.3, Rule 11.7.4, and Rule 11.7.6. [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] However, the disclosure must still contain a defined set of information about the Non-Equivalent Estimates. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] This includes a clear, nearby statement that the estimates are Non-Equivalent Estimates and are not disclosed under a Mining Reporting Standard, that a Competent Person has not done enough work to classify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard, and that it is uncertain whether further evaluation and/or Exploration work will ever allow them to be disclosed that way. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] The Mining Reporting Entity must also provide the sources and dates of the estimates; explain whether any Mineralisation categories used are different from, or the same as, those in a Mining Reporting Standard; and cover relevance, reliability, the work done and key assumptions/methods, and any newer relevant estimates or data with their sources and dates. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] It must also describe what verification work is needed, the proposed timing and funding for that work, identify the classification/reporting standard used, and include a statement by a named Competent Person(s) confirming the accuracy of the information provided for items (3) to (9). [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]

question: For an issue of Securities under an Employee Incentive Scheme that relies on the exception to Rule 9.7.1 based on holder approval within the last three years, how should a Listed Entity treat those scheme issues when applying the 12‑month “Maximum number of Equity Securities” restriction formula—specifically, what meeting-notice disclosures are required for the scheme approval, and how do issues made with that approval affect the “Relevant Issues” subtraction?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity can rely on the Employee Incentive Scheme pathway that treats the scheme issue as an exception to Rule 9.7.1 only if the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities approved the issue of Equity Securities under the scheme within three years before the issue date, and the notice of meeting included specified scheme information. [#SRC:a2108df9-4a76-4d9c-8a4a-7e058e5e8113] For that approval, the notice must cover (i) a summary of the scheme terms, (ii) the number of Securities issued under the scheme since admission to the Official List (or since the last approval under the rule), and (iii) the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme after the approval. [#SRC:a2108df9-4a76-4d9c-8a4a-7e058e5e8113] When the Listed Entity then applies the 12‑month restriction formula that limits new issues to (20% * Base Amount) minus Relevant Issues unless Ordinary Security holders approve, Equity Securities issued (or agreed to be issued) in the prior 12 months with holder approval under Rule 9.7.1 are excluded from “Relevant Issues.” [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Accordingly, scheme issues made pursuant to that Rule 9.7.1 approval are not counted in the “Relevant Issues” figure that is subtracted in the formula, even though they are Equity Securities issued in the 12‑month lookback. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]

question: If a Listed Entity wants to issue Securities under an Employee Incentive Scheme and use the fact that Ordinary Security holders approved it (within the last three years) as an exception, what exactly must have been in the meeting notice, and when the entity later checks the 12‑month 20% issue limit formula, do those approved scheme issues count in “Relevant Issues” or not?
gold_answer: To use the Employee Incentive Scheme route that depends on Ordinary Security holder approval as an exception to Rule 9.7.1, the approval must have occurred within three years before the issue date and the meeting notice must have contained specific scheme disclosures. [#SRC:a2108df9-4a76-4d9c-8a4a-7e058e5e8113] The notice needs to include a summary of the scheme terms, the number of Securities already issued under the scheme since the Listed Entity’s Securities were admitted to the Official List (or since the last approval under the same rule), and the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme after the approval. [#SRC:a2108df9-4a76-4d9c-8a4a-7e058e5e8113] Separately, the 12‑month restriction on new issues says the Listed Entity must not issue (or agree to issue) more Equity Securities than (20% * Base Amount) minus Relevant Issues unless Ordinary Security holders approve. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] In that formula, “Relevant Issues” counts Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months, but it specifically excludes issues made with holder approval under Rule 9.7.1 (and certain other categories). [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] So, if the scheme issues were made under that Rule 9.7.1 approval, they are not included in “Relevant Issues” for the subtraction step. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]

question: When an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business plans to deposit Client Money into a Client Account established with a Third-Party Agent, what specific written acknowledgment must it obtain from the Third-Party Agent, and how should that acknowledgment be treated within the Authorised Person’s Resolution Pack record set?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must obtain a written acknowledgment from the Third-Party Agent before it deposits Client Money into a Client Account established with that Third-Party Agent. [#TGT:4b3b6294-0035-4dd7-b254-827c825338b9] That acknowledgment must state (i) that all Money standing to the credit of the account is held by the Authorised Person on behalf of its Clients, and (ii) that the Third-Party Agent has no entitlement to combine the account with any other account or to assert any charge, mortgage, security, lien, right of set-off, combination, or counterclaim against Money in the account for amounts owed to it by the Authorised Person. [#TGT:4b3b6294-0035-4dd7-b254-827c825338b9] From a records and resolution-planning perspective, the Authorised Person must ensure that records relating to Third-Party Agent acknowledgment in respect of Client Money are included in its Resolution Pack. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] In practice, this means the written acknowledgment obtained as a precondition to depositing Client Money should be retained and organized as part of the Resolution Pack materials covering Third-Party Agent acknowledgment for Client Money, alongside the other specified Resolution Pack records (such as master lists of Client Accounts and the most recent reconciliations). [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]

question: If an Authorised Person is going to put Client Money into a Client Account with a Third-Party Agent, what does the Third-Party Agent’s written acknowledgment need to say, and does that acknowledgment need to be kept in the Resolution Pack?
gold_answer: Before the Authorised Person deposits Client Money into a Client Account that is established with a Third-Party Agent, it must first get a written acknowledgment from that Third-Party Agent. [#TGT:4b3b6294-0035-4dd7-b254-827c825338b9] The acknowledgment has to confirm that the Money in the account is held by the Authorised Person for its Clients, and it must also confirm the Third-Party Agent cannot merge that account with other accounts or use the Money as security or to set off or counterclaim against debts the Authorised Person owes the Third-Party Agent. [#TGT:4b3b6294-0035-4dd7-b254-827c825338b9] Separately, the Authorised Person’s Resolution Pack must include records covering Third-Party Agent acknowledgment in respect of Client Money. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] Putting these together, the written acknowledgment you obtain as a condition of depositing Client Money should be retained in a way that allows it to be included within the Resolution Pack record set for Third-Party Agent acknowledgment relating to Client Money, along with the other Resolution Pack items required for Client Money and Client Investments (for example, master lists of Client Accounts and the most recent reconciliations). [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]

question: Before an Authorised Person establishes a business relationship with a Retail Client and also intends to offer OTC Leveraged Products (or provide advice or make arrangements relating to them), what combined pre-engagement assessment must the Authorised Person perform, and what conclusions must it be able to reach about the Retail Client?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must complete a pre-engagement evaluation that both (i) considers the Retail Client’s understanding of risk and potential loss magnitude before establishing the business relationship and (ii) satisfies the specific OTC Leveraged Products gating test before offering, advising on, or arranging those products. [#SRC:e79e3adf-b4c6-4c32-81c3-6440c56574a6] [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0] Practically, this means the Authorised Person should, prior to establishing the relationship, consider whether the Retail Client demonstrates an understanding of the risks and the potential magnitude of losses they may be exposed to. [#SRC:e79e3adf-b4c6-4c32-81c3-6440c56574a6] In addition, the Authorised Person is prohibited from offering OTC Leveraged Products, or providing advice or making arrangements on behalf of the Retail Client relating to OTC Leveraged Products, unless it has first assessed the Retail Client’s skill, experience, knowledge, financial resources, and risk tolerance. [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0] The assessment must be completed to a level that allows the Authorised Person to reasonably conclude that the Retail Client has adequate experience and skill to understand the potential risk of loss involved in investing in OTC Leveraged Products and has liquid financial resources sufficient to absorb potential losses from trading in those products. [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0]

question: For an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, how should the requirement to perform accurate reconciliations of Client Accounts at least every calendar month be reflected in the contents of the Resolution Pack, and what specific reconciliation-related record must be included?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must both (i) run accurate reconciliations of Client Accounts on a schedule that is as frequent as needed but no less than monthly, and (ii) ensure the Resolution Pack contains evidence of those reconciliations in the form of the most recent reconciliation records for Client Money and Client Investments. [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] The monthly reconciliation obligation is framed as a systems-and-controls requirement aimed at ensuring reconciliations are accurate and performed at least every calendar month, so the firm should operate controls that reliably produce reconciliation outputs on that cadence (or more often where necessary). [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b] To align the Resolution Pack with that operational requirement, the Pack must include the most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments, which provides a concrete, current record demonstrating that reconciliation activity is being performed and documented. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] In practice, this means the firm should be able to point from its monthly (or more frequent) reconciliation process for Client Accounts to the latest completed reconciliation records for Client Money and Client Investments that are filed in the Resolution Pack. [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]

question: For an Issuer conducting an Exempt Offer under Rule 4.3.1(13), how should the Issuer reconcile the requirement that the Product Summary Note carry a prominent front-page disclaimer with the general prohibition on including disclaimers in relation to information disclosed in, or in respect of, the Product Summary Note?
gold_answer: In an Exempt Offer under Rule 4.3.1(13), the Issuer is required to include a specific prominent disclaimer on the front of the Product Summary Note, in bold, using the disclaimer referenced in Rule 4.3.4. [#TGT:624cf5d5-aef8-4bd2-9587-d41858b3ede2] At the same time, Issuers are generally required to refrain from including disclaimers relating to information disclosed in the Product Summary Note or disclaimers made in respect of the Product Summary Note. [#SRC:6d1b4cca-e1ac-42ee-bfe9-70c2c65bcf04] Read together, the Issuer should treat the front-page disclaimer mandated for the Exempt Offer Product Summary Note as the only disclaimer content that is affirmatively required, and avoid adding any other disclaimer language that would operate as a disclaimer “in relation to” the information in the Product Summary Note or “in respect of” the Product Summary Note. [#TGT:624cf5d5-aef8-4bd2-9587-d41858b3ede2] [#SRC:6d1b4cca-e1ac-42ee-bfe9-70c2c65bcf04] This approach aligns with the Product Summary Note content controls that it must be fair and balanced, not false or misleading, and must not omit information in a way that makes any part false or misleading, which would be undermined by additional disclaimer-style qualifications. [#TGT:624cf5d5-aef8-4bd2-9587-d41858b3ede2]

question: For a Listed Entity/Reporting Entity preparing its annual financial report, how should it address the separate obligation to comply with Rule 9.2.10 on annual reporting of Corporate Governance Principles compliance, and what specific disclosures must appear in that annual financial report to satisfy the annual reporting on compliance requirements?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity/Reporting Entity should treat its annual financial report as the vehicle that must contain the required annual compliance disclosures, while also recognizing that it has an additional, explicit obligation to comply with Rule 9.2.10 regarding annual reporting of its compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles. [#SRC:88ccc385-cfe8-4e4e-afd3-80026e74b4dd] In the annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which the annual reporting section applies, the report must first state whether the best practice standards in APP 4 (the Corporate Governance Principles) have been adopted. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] If adoption is not full (including partial adoption), the report must explain the reasons for not fully adopting the standards and describe any actions taken to achieve compliance to the extent standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] The annual financial report must also include a statement by Directors on whether, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, supported by information, assumptions, and any necessary qualifications. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] These annual financial report disclosures should be prepared in a way that enables the entity to meet the separate Rule 9.2.10 annual reporting compliance obligation. [#SRC:88ccc385-cfe8-4e4e-afd3-80026e74b4dd]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity wants to publish Exploration Results or Mineral Resources/Ore Reserves estimates, what do they need to do first with the Competent Person(s), and what exact Competent Person details must be written into the disclosure (name, job relationship/employer, and professional organisation)?
gold_answer: Before publishing the disclosure, the Mining Reporting Entity must obtain prior written consent from the Competent Person(s) that covers the form and context in which the Exploration Results or the Mineral Resources/Ore Reserves estimates (and the supporting information) will be presented. [#SRC:c30b96f6-edff-4774-b206-68a20fe00ba8] That consent requirement operates alongside the content requirements for the disclosure itself, so the disclosure must also include specific statements about the Competent Person(s). [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] In the disclosure text, the entity must: (1) identify a named Competent Person(s) and state that the disclosure is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by that person(s). [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] (2) For each Competent Person, state whether the person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party; if the person is neither, the disclosure must give the name of the Competent Person’s employer. [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] (3) For each Competent Person, include the name of the professional organisation of which the person is a member. [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] These disclosure statements should be consistent with the form and context that the Competent Person(s) consented to in writing. [#SRC:c30b96f6-edff-4774-b206-68a20fe00ba8]

question: When preparing the annual report explanation referenced in the SOURCE, how should a Reporting Entity frame that explanation so it aligns with the Regulator’s rulemaking scope in TARGET—specifically regarding Corporate Governance principles and standards (including board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees or other persons), fair treatment of Shareholders, and conflicts of interests—and what long-term management outcome should the explanation demonstrate?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity should use the annual report explanation to show, in a practical and outcomes-focused way, how its real-world Corporate Governance practices meet the outcomes that section 73 of the FSMR and the Principles are intended to achieve, rather than merely describing formal structures. [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1] In doing so, the explanation should be framed to reflect the areas the Regulator may prescribe by Rules for Corporate Governance: principles and standards applicable to the Reporting Entity (including requirements that may apply to its board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees, or any other person as appropriate), requirements relating to fair treatment of Shareholders, and provisions addressing conflicts of interests. [#TGT:d0183f42-1701-4885-9dcb-cb96c2d62d6d] The explanation should therefore connect the Reporting Entity’s actual practices to these rule-prescribed governance dimensions and make clear how those practices support an adequate Corporate Governance framework. [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1][#TGT:d0183f42-1701-4885-9dcb-cb96c2d62d6d] The management outcome the explanation should demonstrate is that the framework promotes prudent and sound management in the long-term interest of the Reporting Entity and its Shareholders. [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1]

question: In the annual report explanation mentioned in the SOURCE, what should a Reporting Entity say about its real governance practices so it covers the kinds of Rules the Regulator can set in TARGET (board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees or other persons, fair treatment of Shareholders, and conflicts of interests), and what overall long-term goal should it show?
gold_answer: In the annual report explanation, a Reporting Entity should focus on explaining how its day-to-day Corporate Governance practices actually deliver the outcomes expected under section 73 of the FSMR and the Principles, rather than treating the explanation as a purely formal statement. [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1] To make that explanation complete, it should be organized in a way that maps to the areas the Regulator may set by Rules for Corporate Governance: the principles and standards that apply to the Reporting Entity (including requirements that can apply to its board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees, or any other person as appropriate), requirements about fair treatment of Shareholders, and provisions that deal with conflicts of interests. [#TGT:d0183f42-1701-4885-9dcb-cb96c2d62d6d] This linkage helps show how the Reporting Entity’s actual practices are intended to achieve compliance with the outcomes behind the governance framework requirement. [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1][#TGT:d0183f42-1701-4885-9dcb-cb96c2d62d6d] The overall goal the explanation should demonstrate is that the governance framework supports prudent and sound management over the long term, in the interest of both the Reporting Entity and its Shareholders. [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1]

question: When may deferred publication of transaction information be authorised for a large transaction, and how must the firm determine whether the transaction meets the relevant minimum qualifying size by using the ADT-based thresholds and permitted delays table?
gold_answer: Deferred publication may be authorised only where the trade is between a Member (or, where applicable, an Authorised Person) acting on own account and that firm’s Client, and the transaction size is at or above the relevant minimum qualifying size for the instrument and transaction. [#SRC:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48] To determine whether the size condition is met, the firm must first classify the Financial Instrument (admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange) by its average daily turnover (ADT) calculated under the Rule 3.6.10 methodology, and then apply the table’s ADT band and the chosen permitted publication delay to identify the corresponding minimum qualifying size threshold. [#SRC:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48] The table links each permitted delay (e.g., 60 minutes, 180 minutes, until end of trading day, or later trading-day-based delays) to ADT ranges and specifies the minimum qualifying size as either a fixed amount, a percentage of ADT, or a max/min expression depending on the ADT band. [#TGT:096764ad-3a3c-4347-9345-61ad740d7e27] Any authorisation for deferred publication cannot extend beyond the maximum deferral period specified for the relevant class of Financial Instrument and transaction. [#SRC:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48]

question: For a Financial Instrument admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, how do the eligibility conditions for deferred publication interact with the table’s rule that an end-of-trading-day delay may roll over to 12pm of the next trading day when the trade occurs in the final 12 hours of the trading day?
gold_answer: A firm can only use any deferred publication delay (including an end-of-trading-day delay) if the underlying transaction meets the eligibility criteria: it must be between a Member (or, if applicable, an Authorised Person) dealing on own account and a Client of that firm, and it must be at least the relevant minimum qualifying size. [#SRC:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48] The minimum qualifying size is not a single fixed number; it is determined by classifying the Financial Instrument (admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange) by its ADT (calculated under Rule 3.6.10) and then selecting the threshold in the table that corresponds to both the ADT band and the intended permitted delay. [#SRC:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48] If the firm selects the “until end of trading day” permitted delay, the table provides a timing modification: where the trade is undertaken in the final 12 hours of the trading day, the publication deadline may roll over to 12pm of the next trading day. [#TGT:096764ad-3a3c-4347-9345-61ad740d7e27] This roll-over affects only the timing of publication, not the need to satisfy the own-account/client counterparty condition and the ADT-based minimum qualifying size threshold. [#SRC:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48]

question: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity makes a subsequent disclosure that refers back to earlier disclosed estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves (rather than presenting new estimates), what Competent Person-related statements must still appear in the subsequent disclosure, and what conditions must be met to rely on the earlier disclosure for the consent and statement requirements?
gold_answer: A subsequent disclosure that refers to previously disclosed estimates must still include the Competent Person identification statements required for any disclosure containing Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves, and it may rely on the earlier disclosure for the “first-time” consent-and-statement package only if the specific cross-reference and confirmation conditions are met. [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79] In the subsequent disclosure, the Petroleum Reporting Entity must state that the disclosure is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s), disclose whether each Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party (and if not, provide the employer’s name), and identify the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member. [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79] Separately, the prior written consent as to the form and context of how the estimates and supporting information are presented applies only the first time the Petroleum Reporting Entity discloses original or updated estimates, provided that any later disclosure referencing those estimates points back to the earlier disclosure that contained the relevant statement and consent. [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e] The subsequent disclosure must also confirm that the entity is not aware of new information or data that materially affects the earlier disclosure and that the material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the earlier estimates continue to apply without material change. [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e]

question: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity is re-using earlier estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves in a later announcement, what must it say about the Competent Person, and what extra cross-reference and “no material change” confirmation does it need so it can rely on the earlier consent and statement?
gold_answer: In a later announcement that refers to earlier estimates, the Petroleum Reporting Entity must still include the required Competent Person statements for a disclosure that contains Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves, and it can treat the consent-and-statement requirement as already satisfied only if it links back to the earlier disclosure and makes the required confirmations. [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79] The announcement must identify the named Competent Person(s) whose prepared information and supporting documentation the disclosure is based on and which it fairly represents, state whether each Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party (or otherwise give the employer’s name), and name the professional organisation each Competent Person belongs to. [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79] For the consent aspect, the prior written consent about the form and context of presenting the estimates and supporting information is only required the first time the entity discloses original or updated estimates, as long as the later announcement that mentions those estimates points readers to the earlier disclosure that included the statement and consent. [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e] The later announcement must also confirm there is no new information or data that materially affects what was in the earlier disclosure and that the key assumptions and technical parameters behind the estimates have not materially changed. [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e]
